text: Although we do not see the foreground window frame, we se the whole background of a Greenwich Village street. We can see the rear of a number of assorted houses and sm apartment buildings whose fronts face on the next cross-t street, sharply etched by the morning sun. Some are two stories high; others three; some have peaked roofs, others are flat. There is a mixture of brick and w and wrought iron in the construction. The apartment buildings have fire escapes, the others do  not. The neighborhood is not a prosperous one, but neither is poor. It is a practical, conventional dwelling place for  people living on marginal incomes, luck -- or hope and ca planning. The summer air is motionless and heavy with humid heat. It has opened windows wide, pushed back curtains, lifted  blinds and generally brought the neighborhood life into a sweltering intimacy. Yet, people born and bred to life wi earshot and eye glance of a score of neighbors have learn to preserve their own private worlds by uniformly ignorin each other, except on direct invitation. THE CAMERA PULLS BACK until a large sleeping profile of a man fills the screen. It is so large that we do not see a features, but merely the temple and side of the cheek dow which a stream of sweat is running. THE CAMERA PANS OFF this to the right hand side of the wi and MOVES TO a thermometer which is hanging on the wall j outside the window. It registers 84. THE CAMERA MOVES ON into the open, and brings nearer to u room with a large studio window. We are able to see insid this room. A short, balding man is standing near the wind shaving, using a small bowl of water and a portable mirro which he has set up on a shelf. To the right of him is a battered upright piano. On top o the piano is a radio. The music selection coming from the radio stops, and the announcer is heard.
The time -- 7:15 A.M., WOR, New York.  The temperature, outside, 84 --  Friends -- is your life worth one  dollar?

The man shaving quickly puts down his razor, hurries to t radio, and changes the station, moving past a number of  commercial voices until he again finds some music. Contented, he returns to his shaving. THE CAMERA MOVES ON AND OVER to a far building. It passes over the face of this building until it comes to fire esc It goes up and near enough to one which has become the ou bedroom of a couple. We are near enough to see an alarm c hanging from the rail which is now ringing vigorously. A rises lazily to a sitting position. He gropes to switch t alarm off. We see that his pajamas are stained with sweat. In his si position he leans forward and shakes somebody beside him. our surprise, the head of this other person -- a woman -- rises where his feet are. They have been sleeping in oppo directions. They sit limply looking at each other with  bedraggled and weary expressions which show they enjoyed  very little sleep in the heat of the night. THE CAMERA NOW MOVES DOWN toward the left onto another lo building. It MOVES IN A LITTLE to a living room window. J inside the windowsill, a small fan is oscillating. The fa sits on the right side of the table, and to the left of i is an automatic toaster. Behind the toaster stands a full-bodied young woman,  apparently wearing only a pair of black panties. Her stom navel, and the lower part of her chest are naked. Just be her breasts, the curtain, partly drawn, has thrown a deep shadow which extends upward, hiding her breasts, shoulder and head. Two pieces of toast pop up in the toaster. She  takes them out, butters them. Then she turns around and b over another table on which stands an automatic coffee-ma She picks up the coffee-maker, and swings back to the tab to sit down. She does this so deftly that her breasts are never exposed, but hidden by the fan as she sits down. Th fan moves back and forth as she pours coffee, far enough reveal that she wears no bra, but not far enough to fulfi the exciting promise of her lack of clothes. THE CAMERA MOVES ON to a distant street corner seen betwe two buildings. The traffic is very light at this hour, bu Sanitation Department truck moves through the intersectio spraying water out behind it to cool the pavement and kee the dust down. Three little kids in bathing suits run beh the truck, playing in the water. THE CAMERA MOVES OFF and around to some buildings at the  side. As it skims this building, we see a hand emerge fro one of the windows, and remove the cover from a birdcage  which is hanging from a hook on the wall outside. In the  cage are two lovebirds -- arguing. THE CAMERA NOW PULLS BACK SWIFTLY and retreats through th open window back into Jefferies' apartment. We now see mo of the sleeping man. THE CAMERA GOES IN far enough to sho head and shoulders of him. He is L. B. JEFFERIES. A tall, lean, energetic thirty fiv his face long and serious-looking at rest, is in other  circumstances capable of humor, passion, naive wonder and the kind of intensity that bespeaks inner convictions of  moral strength and basic honesty. He is sitting in an Everest and Jennings wheelchair. THE CAMERA PANS along his right leg. It is encased in a  plaster of Paris spica from his waistline to the base of toes. Along the white cast someone has written "Here lie broken bones of L. B. Jefferies." THE CAMERA PANS to a nearby table on which rests a shatte and twisted Speed Graphic Camera, the kind used by fast-a news photographers. On the same table, the CAMERA PANS to an eight by ten glo photo print. It shows a dirt track auto racing speedway,  taken from a point dangerously near the center of the tra A racing car is skidding toward the camera, out of contro spewing a cloud of dust behind it. A rear wheel has come the car, and the wheel is bounding at top speed directly  into the camera lens. THE CAMERA MOVES UP to a framed photograph on the wall. It is a fourteen by ten print, an essay in violence, havi caught on film the exploding semi-second when a heavy  artillery shell arches into a front-line Korean battle  outpost. Men and equipment erupt into the air suspended i solution of blasted rock, dust and screeching shrapnel. T the photographer was not a casualty is evident, but surpr when the short distance between the camera and the explos is estimated. A signature in the lower right hand corner the picture reads -- "L. B. Jefferies." THE CAMERA PANS to a second photograph of a picket line a an aircraft plant strike. Strikers, non-strikers and poli are embroiled in a bitter and confused riot. Clubs, fists and truncheons swing, blood flows, faces twi with emotion and fallen victims struggle to regain their  feet. The picture represents no distant, cautions photogr observation, but rather an intimate report, so immediate real that the viewer has the nervous feeling the fight  surrounds him and he had best defend himself. The same  signature, "L. B. Jefferies," is in the corner. THE CAMERA PANS TO another framed picture, this one a  beautiful and awesome shot of an atomic explosion at  Frenchman's Flat, Nevada. It is the cul-de-sac of violenc The picture taken at a distant observation point, shows s spectators in the foreground watching the explosion throu binoculars. THE CAMERA MOVES ON to a shelf containing a number of cam photographic film, etc. It then PAN ACROSS a large viewer which is resting a negative of a woman's head. From this, THE CAMERA MOVES ON to a magazine cover, and  although we do not see the name of the magazine, we can s the head on the cover is the positive of the negative we  have just passed. THE CAMERA FINALLY COMES TO REST ON a pile of magazines - perhaps a hundred or so. They are all of the same publica

The screen is filled with the top of a desk. In addition the usual telephones, blotting pad, etc., the most promin feature is the number of glossy photo prints, and even la sized mat prints. Some of them have slips pasted over wit descriptions. The center of the desk is occupied by a lar layout of photographs on one magazine page. Behind this w hear the murmur of two voices of men who can be vaguely s beyond the desk. THE CAMERA PANS UP and we are now face to face with IVAR  GUNNISON and JACK BRYCE. Gunnison is sitting on a window- ledge, and beyond him we realize we are high above the Ne York streets. Bryce leans against a wall at right angles him. Gunnison is holding a cablegram in his hand. Bryce has a  cigarette in his mouth. He scratches a match, and is abou to light it, when he notices that Gunnison, still reading the cable, has reached into an inside shirt pocket, and  produced a cigarette. Quickly, Bryce moves over to light  Gunnison's cigarette. Then he settles back to light his o Gunnison doesn't even bother to thank him.
(Looks up) Indo-China -- Jeff predicted it would  go sky-high.
From the looks of Davidson's cable,  it might even go higher than that.  And we haven't even got a camera  over there.
(Stands) This could go off in a month -- or  an hour.
I'll pull somebody out of Japan.
(Heads for his phone) Bryce, the only man for this job is  sitting right here in town. (Picks up phone) Get me L. B. Jefferies.
(Puzzled) Jefferies?
(To Bryce; still  holding phone) Name me a better photographer.
(He can't) But his leg!
Don't worry -- it comes off today.
Bryce gives Gunnison a startled look.
I mean the cast. (To phone)
Shooting through the open window, onto Jeff. He is shavin himself with an electric razor as the phone rings. He shu off the shaver, picks up the phone.
Jefferies.
(On filter) Congratulations, Jeff.
For what?
For getting rid of that cast.
Who said I was getting rid of it?
At this moment, his attention is drawn to something acros the way. He looks up, expectantly. There is almost a touc of eagerness in his expression.

While Jeff is continuing his phone conversation, we see t object of his look. Two pretty girls have appeared on the distant roof. They are smiling and talking, although we c hear their dialogue. Each wears a terrycloth robe. With t backs to the CAMERA, they take off the robes, slipping th down over their shoulders slowly. Then, seductively, they turn -- revealing the full beauty of their tanned and bat suited bodies. It is almost as if they want to be noticed the center of neighborhood attention. They at least have of Jeff's attention. Then they spread the robes in front them, and lie down on the roof, and out of sight. Jeff se a little disappointed.
During the whole of this previous action, the conversatio between Jeff and Gunnison has gone on as follows:
(With logical proof) This is Wednesday.
Gunnison -- how did you get to be  such a big editor -- with such a  small memory?
Wrong day?
Wrong week. Next Wednesday I emerge  from this plaster cocoon.
That's too bad, Jeff. Well, I guess  I can't be lucky every day. Forget I  called.
Yeah. I sure feel sorry for you,  Gunnison. Must be rough on you  thinking of me wearing this cast  another whole week.
Gunnison is now seated at his desk, with the phone receiv to his ear. His assistant, Bryce, can be seen vaguely in background.
That one week is going to cost me my  best photographer -- and you a big  assignment.
Jeff asks, eagerly and alertly.
Where?
We hear Gunnison's reply.
There's no point in even talking  about it.
Jeff's eyes become set upon something else in the neighbo he sees.

Jeff's attention is now drawn to another feature of his  backyard entertainment. THE CAMERA IS NOW FOCUSED on the  window of the small building where we earlier saw the gir behind the oscillating fan. Loud ballet music is pouring  from her open window. The girl, now dressed in dark and  revealing leotard, and ballet slippers, has just turned a from a portable record player. She begins the first grace movement of a modern ballet interpretation. She gracefully moves across the room to the rhythm of the music and dance, toward the ice box. With her feet still  moving, she throws open the door, and then rhythmically m back to the center of the room, gnaws the chicken bone,  occasionally waving it in the air as part of the choreogr She now twirls over toward a table at the other side of t room on which is an open package of bread slices, some bu nearby. With swaying body, she puts down the chicken leg, and  gracefully and rhythmically butters a slice of bread. She picks up both bread and chicken leg and continues her interpretive dance, alternately munching the bread and bu and chicken leg.
Jeff's eyes drop from the ballet dancer's room to the one underneath.

THE CAMERA PANS from the window of the dancing girl, to t window below. Someone is reading the New York Herald Trib The paper lowers, and we see an elderly lady, in her late sixties. She is a faded, refined type. She looks up in th direction of the music and in a calm routine fashion adju the volume of her hearing aid. She resumes her reading.
Jeff is amused by what he sees, but continues his convers with Gunnison, which has gone on through all the scenes w the ballet dancer.
(Insistent) Where?
(Filter) Indo-China. Got a code tip from the  bureau chief this morning. The place  is about to go up in smoke.
(Pleased; excited) Didn't I tell you! Didn't I tell you  it was the next place to watch?
You did.
(On filter) Okay. When do I leave? Half-hour? An  hour?
With that cast on -- you don't.
(On filter) Stop sounding stuffy. I'll take  pictures from a jeep. From a water  buffalo if necessary.
You're too valuable to the magazine  for us to play around with. I'll  send Morgan or Lambert.
Swell. I get myself half-killed for  you -- and you reward me by stealing  my assignments.
I didn't ask you to stand in the  middle of that automobile race track.
(A little angry) You asked for something dramatically  different! You got it!
(Quietly) So did you. Goodbye, Jeff.
(Won't let him hang  up) You've got to get me out of here!  Six weeks -- sitting in a two-room  apartment with nothing to do but  look out the window at the neighbors!

At this moment we hear the sounds of a piano playing. It is a simple, but broken, melody as if someone was just learning to play the piano, or carefully composing a song It clashes abruptly with the music from the ballet dancer apartment. It irritates Jeff as he looks in the direction the new music.
It's worse than the Chinese water  torture.

We now see the source of the piano music. It comes from t apartment with the studio window which we saw earlier whe the man was shaving and listening to the radio. The short balding man sits at the piano playing a few notes, then  transferring them by pencil to notepaper on the piano rac He continues this process, fighting the interference of t ballet music. The opening bars of his melody are beautifu and ear-catching. It is slow, hard work, and the ballet music finally becom such an interference that he gives up and walks to the wi to look down toward the dancer's apartment. He stands by a table at the window which is littered with records, the morning coffee cup, unwashed, the remains of breakfast, old newspapers, song sheets, etc. He takes a cigarette out of his mouth, looks for an ash t and ends up putting it out in the coffee cup. He then ret to the piano and begins picking out the melody the dancer playing on her record player.
Jeff frowns at the double sound, and raises his voice a  little. He continues the conversation which has been hear all through the previous scene.
Read some good books.
I've been taking pictures so long I  don't know how to read anymore.
I'll send you some comic books.
(Low, tense) Listen -- if you don't pull me out  of this swamp of boredom -- I'll do  something drastic.
Like what?
(On filter) I'll -- I'll get married. Then I'll  never be able to go anywhere.
It's about time you got married --  before you turn into a lonesome and  bitter old man.
Can you see me -- rushing home to a  hot apartment every night to listen  to the automatic laundry, the electric  dishwasher, the garbage disposal and  a nagging wife.
Jeff -- wives don't nag anymore --  they discuss.
Jefferies glances out across to the other apartments as h sees:

We see a three-storied, flat-roofed apartment house. The brick is weather-worn and faded. Each apartment has t windows facing the back, one showing a hallway, one a liv room, and the window on the right opening into a bedroom. On the second floor, a man has entered the living room fr a hallway door. He carries a large aluminum sample case c to salesmen. He sets down the case heavily, removes his h and slowly wipes his brow with the back of his right hand He takes off his coat and tie. His shirt is stained with  sweat underneath. He rolls up his sleeves, and his well- muscled arms heavy with hair confirm his dark, husky buil
With his eyes still focused on the distant apartments, Je continues talking with Gunnison.
Yeah? Maybe in the high rent districts  they discuss -- but in my  neighborhood, they still nag.
Well -- you know best. Call you later,  Jeff.
Next time, have some good news.
He hangs up and resumes his attention on the apartment of the salesman.
The salesman looks toward the bedroom door, hesitates, th reluctantly walks toward it. For a moment he is hidden by the wall.
Jeff shifts his look more to the right.

The man enters the bedroom. We can see a woman lying on t far bed. Near her, a small table is covered with medicine bottles, spoons, boxes of pills, a water pitcher and the  other impedimenta of the chronically ill. The woman sits as the man enters. She takes a wet cloth off her forehead Before the man even reaches her, she begins talking, some vigorously. Pointing to a wristwatch, she seems to be say something such as "You should have been home two hours ag I could be lying here dying for all you'd know -- or care The man stops short of the bed, makes gestures of trying placate her, but she goes on scolding. His attitude chang to weary patience, then irritation, then anger. He shouts back at her, turns and goes out of the room. Back in the living room, he picks up his hat, throws it  against the wall in anger, and leaves the apartment, slam the door behind him.

Jeff's attention is suddenly diverted to himself. His leg under the cast, begins itching. He squirms, tries to move the leg a little. It gives no relief. He scratches the ou of the cast, but the itch gets worse. He reaches for a lo Chinese back scratcher lying on the windowsill. Carefully and with considerable ingenuity, he works it under the ca He scratches, and a look of sublime relief comes over his face. Satisfied, he takes the scratcher out. As he replac it on the windowsill, his attention is drawn back to the  scene outside the window.

We see the man who left his apartment in anger come out o the doorway into the backyard. He is easy to identify thr the color of his garish necktie. In one hand the man carr a small garden hoe and rake, and in the other a pair of  trimming shears. He goes to a small patch of flowers, per three feet square. They are beautiful, multi-colored three foot high zinnias He kneels down, inspects them, touches them affectionatel and with some pride. His anger seems to have left him,  replaced by the kind of peace that flowers bring many peo He stands up, carefully hoes the ground, them rakes it. T he snips a few leaves off the lower parts of the plant.  Finally, he waters them.
Jeff's attention is turned to something else of interest.

Into the next door yard we see emerging from the apartmen below the ballet dancer, the elderly lady. She wear a broad sun hat, dark glasses, and a sunsuit  consisting of pink shorts and halter. She carries a copy the Herald Tribune, and still wears her hearing aid. She  settles into a folding, canvas deck chair. Her skin is dead white, and her body is thin to the point emaciation. No sooner has she settled into her chair, tha she is attracted by the sound of the salesman working in garden. She gets up, walks to the fence, and looks over. notices her, but doesn't speak. She begins gesturing to him how to take care of his flowe He listens for a moment, then looks directly at her. The  strong movements of his mouth show us that he objects  vigorously to the annoyance of her comments. She moves aw from the fence, started and a little shocked.

Jeff is seated in the foreground, in a waist shot. Behind him, the entrance door to his apartment opens. STELLA McGAFFERY comes in. She is a husky, unhandsome, da haired woman who is dressed like a district nurse, with d coat, dark felt hat, with a white uniform showing underne the coat. She carries a small black bag. Stella pauses on the landing to watch Jeff. He doesn't ap to notice her entrance.
(Loud) The New York State sentence for a  peeping Tom is six months in the  workhouse!
He doesn't turn.
Hello Stella.
As she comes down the stairs of the landing, holding on t wrought iron railing with one hand:
And there aren't any windows in the  workhouse.
She puts her bag down on a table. It is worn, and looks a if it belongs more to a fighter than a nurse. She takes o her hat coat, and hangs them on a chair.
Years ago, they used to put out your  eyes with a hot poker. Is one of  those bikini bombshells you always  watch worth a hot poker?
He doesn't answer. She opens the bag, takes out some medi supplies: a thermometer, a stop watch, a bottle of rubbin oil, a can of powder, a towel. She talks as she works.

We've grown to be a race of peeping  Toms. What people should do is stand  outside their own houses and look in  once in a while. (She looks up at him) What do you think of that for homespun  philosophy?
A look at his face shows he doesn't think much of it.
Readers' Digest, April, 1939.
Well, I only quote from the best.
She takes the thermometer out of its case, shakes it down Looks at it. Satisfied, she walks to Jeff. She swings the wheelchair around abruptly to face her.
Jeff starts to protest.
Now look, Stella --
She shoves the thermometer into his mouth.
See it you can break a hundred.
As she leaves him holding the thermometer THE CAMERA PULL BACK as she crosses to a divan. She takes a sheet from  underneath, and covers the divan with it. Talking, all th time.

I shoulda been a Gypsy fortune teller,  instead of an insurance company nurse.  I got a nose for trouble -- can smell  it ten miles away. (Stops, looks at him) You heard of the stock market crash  in '29?
Jeff nods a bored "yes."
I predicted it.
(Around thermometer) How?
Stella stops for a moment, and looks at Jeff challengingl

Simple. I was nursing a director of  General Motors. Kidney ailment they  said. Nerves, I said. Then I asked  myself -- what's General Motors got  to be nervous about? (Snaps her fingers) Overproduction. Collapse, I answered.  When General Motors has to go to the  bathroom ten times a day -- the whole  country's ready to let go.
A patient, suffering look comes over his face. He takes o the thermometer.
Stella -- in economics, a kidney  ailment has no relationship to the  stock market. Absolutely none.
It crashed, didn't it?
Jeff has no answer. Defeated, he puts the thermometer bac into his mouth.
Stella goes on with her work.

I can smell trouble right in this  apartment. You broke your leg. You  look out the window. You see things  you shouldn't. Trouble. I can see  you now, in front of the judge,  flanked by lawyers in blue double- breasted suits. You're pleading,  "Judge, it was only innocent fun. I  love my neighbors like a father." --  The Judge answers, "Congratulations.  You just gave birth to three years  in Dannemora."
THE CAMERA PANS HER over to him. She takes out the  thermometer, looks at it.
Right now I'd even welcome trouble.
(Flatly) You've got a hormone deficiency.
How can you tell that from a  thermometer!
Those sultry sun-worshipers you watch  haven't raised your temperature one  degree in four weeks.

She gets down the thermometer. Sterilizes it with a piece alcohol-soaked cotton in her other hand. She gets behind the wheelchair the CAMERA PULLS back as s pushes it over to the divan. She puts the thermometer awa in its case. Then she helps him off with his pajama top. helps him stand on one foot. He hops one step, then she lowers him, face down, on the  divan. She gets a bottle of rubbing oil.
The CAMERA is very low at one end of the divan. Jeff's he half-buried in the sheet, is large in the fore-ground. Beyond him Stella looms large and powerful-looking.
I think you're right. There is going  to be some trouble around here.
Stella takes a handful of oil, slaps it on his back. He  winces.
I knew it!
Don't you ever heat that stuff up.
Gives your circulation something to  fight. (Begins massaging his  back) What kind of trouble?
Lisa Fremont.
You must be kidding. A beautiful  young woman, and you a reasonably  healthy specimen of manhood.
She expects me to marry her.
That's normal.
I don't want to.
(Slaps cold oils on  him) That's abnormal.
(Wincing) I'm not ready for marriage.
Nonsense. A man is always ready for  marriage -- with the right girl. And  Lisa Fremont is the right girl for  any man with half a brain, who can  get one eye open.
(Indifferent) She's all right.
She hits him with some more cold oil. He winces again.
Behind every ridiculous statement is  always hidden the true cause. (Peers at him) What is it? You have a fight?
No.
(After a pause) Her father loading up the shotgun?
Stella!
It's happened before, you know! Some  of the world's happiest marriage  have started 'under the gun' you  might say.
She's just not the girl for me.
She's only perfect.
Too perfect. Too beautiful, too  talented, too sophisticated, too  everything -- but what I want.
(Cautiously) Is what you want something you can  discuss?
Jeff gives an exasperated look.
It's very simple. She belongs in  that rarefied atmosphere of Park  Avenue, expensive restaurants, and  literary cocktail parties.
People with sense can belong wherever  they're put.
Can you see her tramping around the  world with a camera bum who never  has more than a week's salary in the  bank? (Almost to himself) If only she was ordinary.
Stella sprinkles powder on his back, spreads it around. THE CAMERA PULLS BACK as she helps Jeff to a sitting posi He buttons on his shirt.
You're never going to marry?
Probably. But when I do, it'll be to  someone who thinks of life as more  than a new dress, a lobster dinner,  and the latest scandal. I need a  woman who'll go anywhere, do anything,  and love it.
THE CAMERA MOVES IN as she helps him into the wheelchair, listening to him with exaggerated attention. He, stops as notice her attitude. Then he goes on with less conviction
The only honest thing to do is call  it off. Let her look for somebody  else.
I can just hear you now. "Get out of  here you perfect, wonderful woman!  You're too good for me!"
(After pause) That's the hard part.
She swings him around in front of the window. He starts t look out.

Look, Mr. Jefferies. I'm not educated.  I'm not even sophisticated. But I  can tell you this -- when a man and  a woman see each other, and like  each other -- they should come  together -- wham like two taxies on  Broadway. Not sit around studying  each other like specimens in at  bottle.
There's an intelligent way to approach  marriage.
(Scoffing) Intelligence! Nothing has caused the  human race more trouble. Modern  marriage!
Jeff swings his chair back to look at her.
We've progressed emotionally in --

(Interrupting) Baloney! Once it was see somebody,  get excited, get married -- Now,  it's read books, fence with four  syllable words, psychoanalyze each  other until you can't tell a petting  party from a civil service exam
People have different emotional levels  that --

(Interrupting again) Ask for trouble and you get it. Why  there's a good boy in my neighborhood  who went with a nice girl across the  street for three years. Then he  refused to marry her. Why? -- Because  she only scored sixty-one on a Look  Magazine marriage quiz!
Jeff can't help smiling.
When I married Myles, we were both  maladjusted misfits. We still are.  And we've loved every minute of it.
That's fine, Stella. Now would you  make me a sandwich?
She relaxes.
Okay -- but I'm going to spread some  common sense on the bread. Lisa  Fremont's loaded to her fingertips  with love for you. I'll give you two  words of advice. Marry her.
(Smiles) She pay you much?
Stella leaves for the kitchen in a huff. Jeff turns his c to the window.
Jeff now looks out to see what has happened to the old la and the man with the flowers.
The elderly lady is now asleep in her deck chair, her fac covered with the Herald Tribune. There is no sign of the with the flowers.
Jeff's eyes travel up to the ballet dancer's window.
She is sitting near the window looking into an upright mi Dreamily, and methodically, she is brushing her long copp colored hair.
His eyes are suddenly turned in another direction, sharpl to his left.

He is now looking at the windows of the apartments neares to him. A shade has gone up, and a man, obviously a caret is raising a window with some effort. Having accomplished this, he turns back into the room, and we now see him app a young man and woman who are standing just inside the  doorway. He hands a key to the young man, and then obligi brings in two suitcases which he places on the floor besi them. He gives them a studied, but agreeable nod, then  departs. We now see that the girl has a small hat with a veil, and ornate corsage pinned to her light blue tailored suit. Th boy, who like the girl is perhaps twenty years old, wears dark blue serge suit and a grey felt hat. He takes off th hat, and scales it over to a nearby chair. Quickly they a in each other's arms, kissing passionately, crushing the  girl's corsage and pushing her hat back a little. They pa the boy laughs nervously, and takes a furtive glance out  toward the corridor. He looks back into the room, and bec her to come out. She follows him wonderingly. For a momen both are lost from sight. When they reappear, he is carry her in his arms, over the threshold. He sets her down, cl the door, and they kiss again. They part, still holding hands and looking into each othe eyes. Then slowly, and significantly, she looks toward th open window. He releases her hands, goes to the window an pull down the shade, as she is reaching upward with both  hands to unpin her hat.
There is a soft, understanding look on Jeff's face, and h gives an involuntary sigh. He is unaware that Stella is n standing behind him.
(Quietly) Window shopper.
He freezes, turns slowly to look up at her.

The CAMERA makes a short sweep around the neighborhood sh that some of the rooms are now with their lights on. The CAMERA PULLS BACK into Jeff's apartment until his hea fills the screen. He is asleep. A shadow of some other pe creeps over his face. His eyes start to open. He looks up

The screen is filled with the eyes, nose and mouth of a w coming nearer and nearer to the CAMERA to kiss Jeff. The  face is more or less in shadow, a faint light coming onto the profile from the window. It moves down until the lips move out of her bottom of her screen, and just the remain for fill the screen.
The two big profiles filling the screen. The girl kisses  Jeff firmly, but not passionately. Then her head moves ba an inch or two. She speaks.
(Softly) How's your leg?
Mmmm -- hurts a little.
And your stomach?
Empty as a football.
And you love life?
Not too active.
Anything else bothering you?
Uh-huh.

She gives a low. Warm laugh, and the CAMERA PULLS BACK to show that Lisa has been bending over Jeff's wheelchair fr the side. As she straightens up, it PANS her swiftly over the corner of the room, keeping her in big closeup. She t on a low, hanging light. We see her full facial beauty for the first time. It is a warm, intelligent face.
(As she moves) Reading from top to bottom -- (Light on) Lisa --

The CAMERA FOLLOWS HER quickly to another lamp. She gets little farther away from us so that we now see her down t her waist. She turns on the second lamp and the light sho us that her beauty is not alone in her face.
Carol --
The CAMERA PANS HER over to a third lamp which she turns She is now full figure, beautifully groomed and flawless. Her dress is high-style fashion and dramatic evening wear
Fremont.
Jeff looks across the room at her.
The Lisa Fremont who never wears the  same dress twice?
Only because it's expected of her.
She does a professional model's turn in the dress showing off its features.
Right off the Paris plane. Think it  will sell?
Jeff replies:
Depends on the quote. Let's see --  there's the plane tickets over, import  duties, hidden taxes, profit markups --
-- A steal at eleven hundred dollars.
(A low whistle) That dress should be listed on the  stock exchange.
We sell a dozen a day in this price  range.
Who buys them? Tax collectors?
She laughs pleasantly.
Even if I had to pay, it would be   worth it -- just for the occasion.

She looks down at the long mahogany table beside her whic is littered with a number of his personal effects. Her own handbag is also on the table. As she talks her ey scan the table as if she's looking for something specific
(Off -- puzzled) Something big going on somewhere?
(Looking up from the  table) Going on right here. It's a big night.
(Off) It's just a run-of-the-mill Monday.  The calendar's loaded with them.
Lisa finds what she has been looking for. Picks up an old and cracked cigarette box, examines it as she talks.
It's opening night of the last  depressing week of L. B. Jefferies  in a cast.
(Off) Hasn't been any big demand for  tickets.
She turns to look at him, and moves toward him, carrying cigarette box.
(Smiling) That's because I bought out the house.  This cigarette box has seen better  days.
Lisa facing Jeff in the chair.
Picked it up in Shanghai -- which  has also seen better days.
It's cracked -- and you never use  it. And it's too ornate. I'm sending  up a plain, flat silver one -- with  just your initials engraved.
Now that's no way to spend your hard-  earned money!
I wanted to, Jeff. (A sudden intake of  breath) Oh!
She turns around quickly and dashes to the door, dropping the cigarette box on the table as she passes, THE CAMERA  PANNING with her. She goes up the two steps, stops, turns back to Jeff.
What would you think of starting off  with dinner at the "21"?
You have, perhaps, an ambulance  outside?
She reaches for the doorknob, turns it:
(Simply) Better than that. The "21."

She swings open the door and stands to one side. Framed i the doorway is middle-aged waiter wearing a white linen p jacket with a red collar. He's carrying in one hand a lar portable warming oven, and in the other hand an ice bucke containing a bottle of wine covered with a napkin.
His reaction is one of tender amusement.
Thank you for waiting Carl.
He smiles, nods enters. He goes down the stairs, as she  follows. THE CAMERA GOES with both of them.
Kitchen's on the left. I'll take the  wine.
He hands her the wine bucket and she places it on the tab He moves toward the kitchen.
Good evening, Mr Jefferies.
Hello.
Carl goes into the kitchen.
(Up, to Carl) Just put everything right in the  oven Carl. On "low."
(Off) Yes ma'am.
(Enthusiastically) Let's open the wine now. It's a  Montrachet.
(Appreciatively) A big glassful.
She moves to a small bar set in the wall cabinet. Produces two glasses, hold them up.
Big enough?
Fine. Corkscrew's on the right.
She finds it. Puts the glasses on the table, uncovers the wine, and begins screwing in the corkscrew.
I couldn't think of anything more  boring and tiresome than what you've  been through. And the last week must  be the hardest.
Yeah -- I want to get this thing off  and get moving.
(Struggling with cork) Well, I'm going to make this a week  you'll never forget.
Carl comes out of the kitchen carrying the empty warming  oven. He sets it down he sees Lisa struggling with the  corkscrew.
Let me, madam.

She does. He takes out his own professional corkscrew, qu inserts it and levers the cork out. He deftly wraps the n around the bottle and pours the wine, replacing the bottl in the wine bucket. Lisa has opened her purse to produce  some money, in bills. She hands it to the waiter.
This will take care of the taxi as  well.
Carl, without looking at the money, puts it in his pocket
Thank you, Miss Fremont.
He picks up the warning oven.
Have a pleasant dinner, Mr. Jefferies.
Thank you.

Carl goes up the stairs and out the door, while THE CAMER REMAINS on Lisa and Jeff. She picks up both glasses of wi and walks toward Jeff. She seats herself on the windowsil as she hands him his glass. We notice that the outside is considerably darker by now, and the lights are beginning come on in the various apartments outside. They raise the glasses in a silent toast, and sip the wine. THE CAMERA C IN until they are both in a tight TOW SHOT.
What a day I've had!
Tired?

Not a bit. I was all morning in a  sales meeting. Then over to the  Waldorf for a quick drink with Madame  Dufresne -- just over from Paris.  With some spy reports. Back to the  "21" for lunch with the Harper's  Bazaar people -- that's when I ordered  dinner. Then two Fall showings --  twenty blocks apart. Then I had to  have a cocktail with Leland and Slim  Hayward -- we're trying to get his  next show. (Softly, looking up  to him) Then I had to dash back and change.
(Mock seriousness --  one girl to another) Tell me -- what was Slim Hayward  wearing?
(Seriously) She looked very cool. She had on a  mint green --
She breaks off with a little laugh, and a slight reproach look at Jeff. She sips her drink then says:
And to think, I planted three nice  items about you in the columns today.
Jeff's opinion of that is a short chuckle.
You can't buy that kind of publicity.
That's good news.
Someday you might want to open up  your own studio here.
How could I run it from say --  Pakistan?
She puts down her glass and slides along the window seat  nearer to him, THE CAMERA CLOSING IN. She looks up at him with a serious frankness.
Jeff -- isn't it time you came home?  You could pick your assignment.
I wish there was one I wanted.
Make the one you want.
(As if he can't believe  her) You mean leave the magazine?
Yes.
For what?
For yourself -- and me. (She adds eagerly) I could get you a dozen assignments  tomorrow... fashion, portraits --
Jeff interrupts her with soft laughter.
(Offended) Don't laugh. -- I could do it!
That's what I'm afraid of. (He gazes into space) Could you see me -- driving down to  the fashion salon in a jeep -- wearing  combat boots and a three day beard? (He chuckles at the  thought)
I could see you looking handsome and  successful in a dark blue flannel  suit.
(Looking directly at  her) Let's not talk any more nonsense,  huh?
She stands up. THE CAMERA PULLS BACK.
I'd better start setting up for  dinner.
She moves away behind him, into the kitchen.

Jeff gives a sigh of relief, exhaling his breath, then lo down toward his legs in thought. He holds this attitude f just a moment, then seems to shake off his concern to lif his head and turn his attention to what might be happenin in his neighborhood beyond his window. Behind him we see the vague form of Lisa bringing in a ca table, which she proceeds to unfold.

Jeff's attention is concentrated on an apartment we have seen before. This belongs to a single woman, about forty  years of age. She lives alone. Her apartment is below tha of the salesman with the invalid wife.
Jeff leans forward with increased interest. Behind him we get vague figure of Lisa laying a cloth over the card tab

A nearer view show us a more intimate picture of the woma Jeff is concentrating on. She is thin and unattractive. A the moment, she is putting on her make-up in front of the bedroom mirror. She gives a half turn and picks up a pair horn-rimmed glasses, which she puts on, and leans nearer her mirror. She picks up a lipstick and proceeds to paint her lips carefully. Having completed her make-up, she takes off her glasses a surveys her face in the mirror. She stands up, swings the skirt of her dress around, admires herself in the mirror. She is quite flat-chested, and the dress hangs unattracti She lifts her chin, gives one last look, and turns toward her living room. As if she's preparing to meet someone.
Without taking his eyes from the scene, Jeff picks up his wineglass and drinks. As he drinks, his eyes move slightl over.

THE CAMERA HAS PANNED slightly to the woman's living room window. A small, candle-lit table is set up, with dinner two. The spinster sweeps into the room, smiling. She goes the door, opens it, and in pantomime admits an imaginary  caller. She pretends to kiss him lightly, take his hat, a place the hat on a chair. Then she shows him to a seat at the table, disappears into an unseen kitchen and returns  with a bottle and two glasses. She sits down, pours two  drinks. She lifts her drink in a toast to the imaginary m opposite her.
Jeff gives a faint, sympathetic smile, and subconsciously raises his glass in response. In the background, Lisa, ha just placed a pair of candlesticks on the table, is retur to the kitchen.

Having finished her drink, the lonesome woman pours herse another one. Then she starts to take a sip, smiling acros the table at her imaginary guest. She lowers the glass on the table. The smile fades from her face as her head drop Suddenly she buries her head in her arms over the table a starts to sob.
Jeff, his glass in hand, looks out sympathetically. He is unaware that Lisa is standing behind him, and is also wat this little drama.
That's what is know as "manless  melancholia."
(Nods agreement) Miss Lonely Hearts. At least that's  something you'll never have to worry  about.
Oh? You can see my apartment all the  way up on 63rd street?
Not exactly -- but we have a little  apartment here that's probably about  as popular as yours. (He points) You, of course, remember Miss Torso.
Both of them swing their eyes a little to the left.

The kitchen-lining room combination of the ballet dancer' apartment has now been made more presentable. The ice box is now skillfully concealed by a large Chines screen. All kitchen utensils have been put away, replaced more attractive effects, and lamp light softens the  surroundings. Miss Torso is now wearing a cocktail dress, which shows o her figure to great advantage, especially when she leans  toward three assorted men to offer them a plate of hors d oeuvres. She is the perfect hostess, animated, charming, with an added personal touch for each guest. She is behav with a sophistication which was not apparent when we firs saw her in the morning. Her every movement is followed  admiringly by the eyes of the three men -- one wearing bl tie, with a touch of grey in his hair, a Long Island soci a young rather handsome, actor in grey flannel suit -- an last, a bright, pleasant, young man who might possibly be from Wall street, wearing a blue-pin-striped suit. The la two are engaged in an animated conversation. The young ma in the grey suit is showing the other young man some news cuttings he's taken from his pocket. Miss Torso sees that the cocktail glass of the third man empty. She takes it over to the window, and starts to fil it. The man in the tuxedo follows her over, with a casual glance toward the other two. He stands beside her as she  makes the drink. He looks at his watch with some impatien and makes a side comment to her as to the lateness of the time. She turns, gives him a light kiss on his cheek, as she's telling him to be patient. Instead of pacifying him it makes him more amorous, and he puts an arm around her  shoulder an plants a heavy kiss on her cheek. She turns t face him, they look into each other's eyes a moment, and allows herself to be kissed on the lips -- but only long  enough so as to attract the attention of the other two me With a little admonishing look, she moves away from him, makes him rejoin the other two.
Jeff turns and looks up to Lisa with a grin.
Well, she picked the most prosperous  looking one.
She's not in love with him -- or any  of them.
How can you tell that -- from here?
You said it resembled my apartment,  didn't you?
She moves away with a significant look to him. THE CAMERA MOVES IN until Jeff is in semi-closeup, alone. He ponders over her last remark, then changes his look to another direction.
The newlyweds's apartment has the shades still drawn. Although there's a light burning inside.

There is a slight, but warm, smile on Jeff's face as he l at the drawn shade. His eyes move away from the newlyweds apartment, and slowly explore the neighborhood to his rig He finds something of interest, and stops to stare at it. His face sobers at what he sees.

The salesman's apartment. We see both the living room and the bedroom. The salesman has prepared a dinner tray, and carrying it from the kitchen, through the lining room, in the bedroom. He places it on the lap of his wife, sitting in bed. He puts a couple of pillows behind her back to ma her more comfortable. She doesn't bother to thank him, but is busy examining th content of the tray. Her attitude shows her dissatisfacti Nothing is right. It's not what she wanted, and it's badl prepared. She begins criticizing him. He starts to answer her back, but decides better of it, and instead, leaves t room. He goes to the kitchen reaches up to a wall cabinet takes down a bottle and pours himself a drink. Then he re to the lining room, listens a moment. The wife is grudgin beginning to eat the dinner. The husband quietly lifts a  phone from the cradle, and dials a number.
Jeff becomes completely absorbed with he sees. He leans  forward a little.

We get a better view of the salesman waiting while his  connection is being made. Whoever he has called answers. instantly there is a marked change in his attitude. He  relaxes, smiles, is warm. He talks softly, perhaps guarde with an occasional glance at the bedroom door. In the bed his wife has become aware of the call. Quietly she moves the tray, gets out of bed, and goes to bedroom door to listen. The wall hides her from our view. Then suddenly, she apparently opens the door, because the living room, we see her arm suddenly appear, pointing at man and the telephone. He speaks quickly into the phone, hangs up. His face is flushed and angry as he goes toward the bedroom. In the bedroom his wife appears walking back the bed, followed by the husband. She is laughing, and he answering her in angry tones. She climbs in bed laughing. The more she laughs, the more angry he gets, and the hard she laughs. Finally, he leaves the room, goes into the li room, back into the kitchen and has another drink. He sta there, controlling an outburst of emotion, and seems almo to be crushing the shot glass in his clenched fist.

While Jeff has been engaged in watching this little drama the SOUND of a piano has started. He now diverts his atte from the salesman's apartment to the source of the piano  music. He turns his eyes in the direction of the composer apartment.

Through the studio window of the song-writer's apartment see the man at work again on his original melody, and he farther along the line of the melody than before. It is beginning to take some shape, and give promise of i full beauty.
Jeff, listening to the composer. His head turns as Lisa's voice comes over:
(Emerging from kitchen) Where's that music coming from?
THE CAMERA QUICKLY PULL BACK as Jeff swings his chair aro Lisa is emerging from the kitchen, carrying the serving d of their lobster thermidor.
Oh... some songwriter. In the studio  apartment. Lives alone. Probably had  an unhappy marriage.
(Putting down the  food) I think it's enchanting.
She pulls up a chair and seats herself at the card table. now observe that two small lit candles adorn the table, a the rest of the room lights are out.
Almost as if it were being written  especially for us.
(Pleasantly) No wonder he's having so much trouble  with it.
A faint shade of disappointment is seen on Lisa's face; b she quickly recovers and looks down at the table.
Well, at least you can't say the  dinner isn't right.
Jeff looks at her soberly.
Lisa, it's perfect (Looks down at the  food, without  enthusiasm) As always.
The brightness drains from Lisa's face, and she lowers he eyes slowly toward the table.
Lisa slowly helping Jeff to lobster from the main dish.

Shooting over Jeff's shoulder we see beyond him the divan bed upon which Lisa is stretched out. There is one light  burning, behind Lisa's head. A fierce discussion is in  progress. Lisa gesticulates with her hands, body and legs
There can't be that much difference  between people and the way they live!  We all eat, talk, drink, laugh, sleep,  wear clothes --
Jeff raises both his hands.
Well now, look --
Lisa draws back one leg, and points a finger challengingl
If you're saying all this just because  you don't want to tell me the truth,  because you're hiding something from  me, then maybe I can understand --
There's nothing I'm hiding. It's  just that --
(Won't let him break  in) It doesn't make sense to me. What's  so different about it here from over  there, or any place you go, that one  person couldn't live in both places  just as easily?
Some people can. Now if you'll let  me explain --
(Ignores him) What is it but traveling from one  place to another, taking pictures?  It's just like being a tourist on an  endless vacation.
All right. That's your opinion. You're  entitled to it, but --
It's ridiculous for you to say that  it can only be done by a special,  private little group of anointed  people.
Jeff begin to get desperate.
I made a simple, but true statement  and I'll back it up, if you'll just  shut up for a minute!
Lisa, stretched out on the divan. She looks at him for a  moment without speaking. Then:
If your opinion is as rude as your  manner, I'm not sure I want to hear  it.
We see Jeff's hand coming to the foreground with a restra gesture.
(Soothing her) Lisa, simmer down -- will you?
(Something starts her  up again) You can't fit in here -- I can't fit  in there. According to you, people  should be born, live an die on the  same --
(Loud, sharp) Lisa! Shut up!
Lisa turns on her side, and stares into the room, angrily
After a moment of silence, Jeff says earnestly:
Did you ever eat fish heads and rice?
Of course not.
You might have to, if you went with  me. Ever try to keep warm in a C-54,  at fifteen thousand feet, at twenty  below zero?
Lisa, still looking out into the room, and without turnin says:
Oh, I do that all the time. Whenever  I have a few minutes after lunch.
Ever get shot at, run over, sandbagged  at night because people got  unfavorable publicity from your  camera?
She doesn't answer, obviously annoyed at the unnecessary  questions.
Those high heels would be a lot of  use in the jungle -- and those nylons  and six-ounce lingerie --
(Quickly) Three.
Well, they'd be very stylish in  Finland -- just before you froze to  death. Begin to get the idea?
She turns at last, and looks across at him.
If there's one thing I know, it's  how to wear the proper clothes.
SHOOTING OVER LISA'S SHOULDER, and down her body, with Je in the chair beyond. Jeff says, as if remembering some ol experience:

Huh? Try and find a raincoat in  Brazil. Even when it isn't raining (Squints at her) Lisa, on this job you carry one  suitcase. Your home is the available  transportation. You sleep rarely,  bathe even less, and sometime the  food you even look at when they were  alive!
Jeff, you don't have to be  deliberately repulsive just to impress  me I'm wrong.
If anything, I'm making it sound  good. (A thoughtful pause) Let's face it, Lisa... you aren't  made for that kind of a life. Few  people are.
Lisa realizes she is getting nowhere.
You're too stubborn to argue with.
Jeff, getting angry.
I'm not stubborn! I'm truthful!
Lisa, with sarcasm.
I know. A lesser man would have told  me it was one long holiday -- and I  would have awakened to a rude  disillusionment.
Jeff is definitely angry.
Now if you want to get vicious, I'd  be very happy to accommodate you!
Lisa starts to rise from the divan, THE CAMERA PANNING UP She moves away from THE CAMERA into the center of the roo as she says:
(Wearily) No. I don't particularly want that. (She turns, faces him) So that's it. You won't stay here --  I can't go with you.
Jeff looks across at her with some concern.
It would be the wrong thing.
Lisa, from Jeff's viewpoint.
You don't think either one of us  could ever change?
Right now, it doesn't seem so.
Lisa begins to move around the room assembling her posses preparatory to leaving. She puts a comb, and other effect into a handbag. She gets her stole. All this as she talks.
(Simply) I'm in love with you. I don't care  what you do for a living. Somehow I  would just like to be part of it.
Jeff starts to say something then thinks better of it, an remains silent.
Lisa pauses in the act of gathering her things together.
And it's deflating to find out that  the only way I can be part of it --  is to take out a subscription to  your magazine. I guess I'm not the  girl I thought I was.
There's nothing wrong with you, Lisa.  You have the town in the palm of  your hand.
(Looks at Jeff) Not quite -- it seems. (Tosses a stole over  her shoulder) Goodbye, Jeff.
You mean "goodnight."
I mean what I said.
Jeff's eyes follow her up the steps toward the door. He c out to her, impulsively, as we HEAR the SOUND of the door opening.
Lisa!
Lisa turns in the half-opened door.
Can't we just sort of keep things  status quo?
Without any future?
Jeff tries to be pleasant, and offhand.
Well -- when'll I see you again?
Lisa, standing in the open doorway.
Not for a long time. Not, at least  until -- (She begins smiling) -- tomorrow night.
Continues smiling as she close the door softly behind her
The pleasantness on Jeff's face slowly melts into baffled discouragement. He reaches for a nearby phone picks up th receiver, dials. It buzzes on filter. Receiver up on filter.
(Filter) Hello.
Gunnison?
Yeah. Is that you, Jeff?
It's me.
Something wrong?
The word is "everything." Now what  time does my plane leave Tuesday?
(Unhappy) Jeff --
(Won't give him time  to argue) I don't care where it goes -- just  as long as I'm on it.
(Wearily, after pause) Okay. Indo-China. Tuesday. We'll  pick you up.
That's more like it. Goodnight, old  buddy.
Yeah.
Jeff hangs up, looks up to the door through which Lisa le He's not particularly happy.
Jeff returns to the window. He lights a cigarette and smo it peacefully, as he contemplates the neighborhood.

The CAMERA slowly sweeps over the various apartments with odd window lit here and there. In the distant street ther is still some traffic passing, with one or two pedestrian going by. THE CAMERA completes its sweep, and starts to m back again. Somewhere a dog howls. The PANNING CAMERA com to a sudden halt.

Jeff smiles a little, but as the howl continues, his  expressions sobers. His eyes begin to scan the neighborho as if looking for the source. He fails to find it, and si there, puzzled and disturbed. The scene, and the sound of the dog:

Jeff's chair is turned facing the window so that we see t darkened room behind him. There is just one side light  burning, which illuminates the side of his face. His head nods sleepily as he dozes. He opens his eyes and looks out, as a slight sound of rain starts.

From his viewpoint we see the first few drops of rain sta to fall. It is sort, gentle rain, not a downpour. There a still some windows lit in the neighborhood. The apartment house corridors all have small night lights burning.
Jeff wakens a little more fully as his attentions is draw to:

The couple who sleep on the fire escape. The increasing r cause them to hastily gather their things to retreat insi The man, hurriedly untying the alarm clock from the raili of the fire escape, lets it slip through his fingers. As falls to the garden below, the CAMERA FANS SWIFTLY down w it. When the clock hits the ground, the alarm goes off se a shrill sound through the neighborhood.
Jeff smiles at the incident, and then lowers his eyes sli as something else catches his attention.

Coming out of his apartment into the corridor on the floo below is the salesman with the nagging wife. The shades a drawn in his apartment, but a light burns dimly behind th The salesman carries a large aluminum suitcase -- the sam one we saw him with earlier in the day. The sound of the  alarm startles him. He turns toward the window a moment  listening. Then reassured that is is nothing important, h turns and moves down the corridor.
Jeff is puzzled. He looks down a moment in thought. Then darts his eyes and swings them toward the left. He looks steadily toward the distant street corner.
The street corner, lighted by a lamp, is deserted. A mome later, the salesman, still carrying the suitcase, moves  diagonally across the corner, head down against the rain.
Jeff looks wonderingly at this nocturnal activity. Then h looks down at his wristwatch.
Jeff's watch reads 1:55.
The watch now reads 2:35.
More puzzled, allows his eyes to travel from the street t the apartment corridor.
The salesman is see coming down the corridor to his apart still carrying the aluminum case. He quickly enters his  apartment door in a business-like manner.
Jeff starts to assume a thoughtful air, when he is startl by a light which falls across his face from the right. He looks toward the light.

The light comes from the song-writer's apartment. His doo is open, and he is hanging onto the door frame, his hand  still on the light switch. He surveys his apartment. He  appears rather drunk. He comes into the apartment, closes the door behind him, and sways a little. He wears a hat,  pushed back on his forehead, and no raincoat. His clothes are quite wet. He might have even fallen. He looks disgustedly at the piano, then lurches toward it There is no doubt now as the state of his drunkenness. At the piano he viciously sweeps all the note paper off the  music stand. This seems to give him some satisfaction, bu he loses his balance, twists sideways, and fall into a ne chair. He remains there, bleary-eyed and a little sick.

What he has observed seems to give Jeff an idea. He moves his wheelchair backward and to the left alongside the sid board. Awkwardly, with his left hand, he reaches up for a bottle of whiskey. He cradles the bottle in his lap, and  reaches for a tumbler. He then wheels back to the window, and pours himself a good, long drink. He lifts up the gla starts to drink, but something happening beyond his windo startles him and he stops in the middle of his drink, his eyes a little wider then usual.
The salesman is again leaving his apartment with his alum suitcase.
Jeff's eyes travel down to the street.
A brief moment or two. Then the salesman, carrying his  aluminum case, crosses the street.
Jeff's face is expressionless. He just stares.

Jeff's head is nodding and dozing again. The side light f the song-writer's apartment is no longer on his face. Jef eyes open, then his head comes up quickly, trying to clea the sleep from his mind, as he remembers the object of hi vigilance.
The salesman's apartment shows the shades drawn and a dim light burning behind them. The CAMERA PANS to the empty  corridor.
Jeff's eyes turn sharply in the direction of the street.

The street is deserted. At the right hand side of the scr a light goes on. THE CAMERA PANS OVER and we see that Mis Torso has returned from her date. She is wearing a three- quarter length coat over her evening dress. She is inside with the door two-thirds closed, but she leans out to kis someone goodnight. Then it takes some coaxing to get the  door completely closed. She turns the key in the lock. She listens a moment then  comes to the center of the room. She takes her coat off a drapes it over chair. She removes the screen in front of ice box, then opens the ice box. She searches it for something to eat; finds a big piece o pumpkin pie. She closes the ice box. She starts to eat th pie as she moves in the direction of the bathroom. Stoppi a moment, she puts the piece of pie on a table, and proce to take off her dress. Undoing the zippers, she slides it over her head as she passes into the bathroom. The dress thrown on a nearby chair, and the bare arm picks up a pie of pie. She is now in the bathroom. We see her slip down brassiere straps, but the window does not permit us to se any lower. As she munches on the pie, she pulls out a few pins holding up her hair, which she proceeds to brush  rhythmically. She turns and moves down her bare back.
Jeff's eyes suddenly switch to the street.

We catch a quick glimpse of the salesman, just passing th alleyway, suitcase in hand. The CAMERA PANS across the ba dancer's apartment, over to the salesman's apartment. It  waits, until he appears in the corridor. He enters his apartment.
Jeff sits in his wheelchair, looking quietly out at the  neighborhood, sleep beginning to take hold on him again.
THE CAMERA PANS slightly over the whole of the neighborho The lights in Miss Torso's apartment snap out. Only one l remains. It burns behind the drawn shades of the salesman apartment.

A big head of Jeff. He is still in his wheelchair, sound  asleep. The CAMERA PANS off his face, out through the win The rain has stopped, and the general light of dawn is co up. The CAMERA COMES TO REST on the salesman's apartment corridor, which is still dimly lit by the electric lights We see the salesman emerge into the corridor, pause a mom to allow a woman to proceed him.
