On long rope, the woman is lowering an open wicker basket in which sits a small dog. When is reaches the yard below, t CAMERA PANNING DOWN, the dog steps out and runs off to ex the yard. The woman pulls up the basket, and leaves it on the fire escape. The CAMERA PULL BACK into Jeff's apartme where Stella is busy massaging Jeff's back at he lies fac down on the divan.
You'd think the rain would have cooled  things off. All it did was make the  heat wet.
Stella hits a sore muscle in Jeff's back. He jumps.
That's a stiff one.
A low camera has Jeff's head on the foreground, with Stel just behind him, at work on his back. She attacks the sor muscle vigorously.
The insurance Company would be a lot  happier if you slept in your bed,  not the wheelchair.
(Between clenched  teeth) How did you know!
Eyes bloodshot. Must have been staring  out the window for hours.
I was.
(Massaging harder) What'll you do if one of them catches  you?
Depends one which one.
She stops massaging, reaches for the oil.
Now Miss Torso, for example --
Stella hits his back with a palmful of cold oil. It takes his breath.
Keep your mind off her.
She's real eat, drink and be merry  girl.
And she'll end up fat, alcoholic and  miserable.
Speaking of misery, Miss Lonely Hearts  drank herself to sleep again. Alone.
Poor girl. Someday she'll find her  happiness.
And some man will lose his.
Isn't there anyone in the neighborhood  who might cast an eye in her  direction?
Well, the salesman could be available  soon.
(Interested in the  scandal) He and his wife splitting up?
It's hard to figure. He went out  several time last night, in the rain  carrying his sample case.
(So?) Isn't he a salesman?
Now what could he sell at three in  the morning?
(Shrugs) Flashlights. Luminous dials for  watches. House numbers that light  up.
He was taking something out of the  apartment. I'm certain.
She helps him to a sitting position.
His personal effects. He's probably  running away -- the coward.
Sometimes it's worse to stay than it  is to run.
(Looks at him) But it takes a particularly low type  of man to do it.
Jeff turns his head away for a moment. She helps him into the chair. Hands him his shirt, which he proceeds to put The back of his chair is to the window.
(Putting oil and power  away) What about this morning? Any  developments?
No. The shades are still drawn in  their apartment.
(stops) In this heat? (Turns, looks over  his shoulder) They're up now.
He quickly turns his wheelchair around to the window unti he is in profile.

The salesman, having just raised the shades in the living room, is now looking out the window. It is not a casual l but a long, careful, searching appraisal of all the apart house windows in his neighborhood, starting from his left his right. His eyes move closer toward Jeff's apartment.
Jeff in his chair, facing the window, Stella beside him.  Jeff nearly knocks the startled Stella off her feet with arm.
Get back! Out of sight! Quick!
He propels his chair backward quickly, and Stella moves t the side with surprising agility. They are both in shadow
(A startled whisper) What is it? What's the matter?
Jeff keeps his eyes trained on the window.
(Quietly) The salesman's looking out his window.
Stella relaxes, gives Jeff a disgusted look, and starts t move out of the shadows.
A Federal offense.
(Sharply) Get back there! He'll see you!
She moves back into the shadows.
I'm not shy. I've been looked at  before.
(Still peering toward  window) It's not an ordinary look. It's the  kind of look a man gives when he's  afraid somebody might be watching  him.
The salesman completes his searching glance at the  neighborhood. Then something directly below his window ca his attention. He looks sharply downward, his body visibl tensing.
Jeff, with a restraining hand to Stella, begins to edge h chair cautiously forward so that he can see what the sale is looking at.

THE CAMERA MOVES FORWARD, and as it reaches the edge of t window, PANS DOWN and shows us what the salesman is looki at. The little dog that was lowered in the basket is snif at the salesman's personal flower bed.
Jeff's eyes move up quickly to look at the salesman.

The salesman leans forward and grips the window sill as h watches the dog. The CAMERA PANS DOWN and we now see that the old lady with the hearing aid is leaning over the fen admonishing the dog. We can faintly hear her voice saying something to the effect that he'll get into trouble. The turns to glance at her and apparently taking heed, moves  away. The old lady is wearing a faded house-robe.
Jeff is amused at the dog incident. Behind him, Stella mo to the center of the room, saying:
Goodbye, Mr. Jefferies. I'll see you  tomorrow.
(Grunts) Uh-huh.
She begins putting her equipment back into her black bag. Jeff's eyes lift to the salesman's apartment, and the  amusement drains from his face. He leans forward a little tensely.
The salesman has his aluminum case on the table near the  center of the room. He is carefully wiping out the interi with dust cloth.
Jeff watching intently. Stella putting the last of her th into her bag.
And don't sleep in the chair again.
Jeff continues to what the salesman, his face showing a g concentration of thought.
Uh-huh.
Stella picks up her bag, stares at Jeff's back a moment,  then starts for the door.
Uh-huh. Uh-huh. Great  conversationalist.
Jeff swings half-way around in his chair just as Stella  reaches the top of the steps.
Stella.
She turns around. Jeff points to a coat-stand near the do
(Goes on quickly) Will you take those binoculars out  of the case and bring them to me.

She puts down her bag, reaches for the binoculars, takes  them out the case. She comes down the stairs, brings them him. He immediately swings to the window, and lifts them his eyes. Stella sniffs, then goes to the door, as she sa
Trouble. I cam smell it. I'll be  glad when they crack that cast, and  I get out of here.
As Stella goes out the door, the CAMERA MOVES IN until Je head, and the binoculars, are filling the screen.
The salesman has completed his cleaning of the case. He i in the act of placing it on the floor. He turns and again glances out of the window.
Jeff quickly lowers the binoculars and edges back a few  inches. He watches a moment, then cautiously lifts the  binoculars again.

The man is now moving out of the living room, and the  binoculars PAN him though to the small kitchen which is s through a side window. The man starts to busy himself in this kitchen with his b to us, but the image is very unsatisfactory.

Jeff lowers the binoculars and there is an expression of  exasperation on his face. He throws the binoculars down, then looks about him. He backs his chair up quickly towar the main cabinet on his left. He leans down, opens a cupb door and takes out a long-focus lens. Then from a shelf a he takes a small Exacta camera. He quickly takes off the  existing lens and puts on the telephoto lens in its place He wheels himself back to the window and raises the camer to his eye.

Through the view-finder of the camera, we are now brought into close proximity with the salesman in his little kitc His back is still to us. He half-turns and takes a used  newspaper. He spreads it open, along the drainboard. From the sink he takes out a large butcher's knife, and a long narrow saw. They disappear from sight as he lays them on newspaper and proceeds to wrap them up. Having completed job, he emerges from the kitchen carrying the newspaper- wrapped parcel. For a moment he is lost behind the wall that separates th kitchen recess from the living room. He does not reappear for a moment.
Jeff lowers the camera for a moment, and watches tensely. Suddenly he puts it up to his eye again.

Half of a man's body is now seen in the living room. Then the salesman turns and moves to the center of the ro He is not carrying anything. He sits down on a couch, wit display of fatigue. He yawns and stretches out of sight a full length on the couch.
Jeff lowers the camera. He watches the living room for a  moment. Then his eye travels briefly back to the kitchen; then return to the living room. His brow knits a little a we:

The thermometer outside of Jeff's window, registering 83  degrees. The CAMERA PANS OFF to the left until it comes t rest on the song-writer's studio. He is dressed only in  bathing trunks, and is vigorously cleaning his rug with a carpet sweeper. In the middle of his sweeping, he stops,  hurries a step or two to the piano. He plays a couple of  notes with one hand, while he stands. Listens, plays them again. Decides they are no good, and  returns to his carpet sweeping. THE CAMERA PANS FARTHER LEFT to the salesman's apartment. There are no lights burning behind the drawn shade of the bedroom, but the living room and the kitchen are lighted. There is no sign of the salesman. THE CAMERA CONTINUES ITS PAN to the left, to include the  couple who sleep on the fire escape in the hot weather. We now get an opportunity to examine these people more  closely. The man is balding, and middle-aged. He is weari striped pajamas. He is in the act of laying out the mattr His wife is slightly younger, peroxided, faded show girl  type. Also wearing pajamas, with a fluffy handkerchief in the left pocket, the wife is leaning over the railing hol onto the rope which leads to the dog's basket now on the  floor of the courtyard. Having been a one-time siffleuse, her call to the dog is clarion and melodic.

The little dog emerges reluctantly from the shadows, and  steps into the basket. It begins to move upward, and THE  CAMERA FOLLOWS it. When the basket reaches the fire escap THE CAMERA PANS ON to the apartment of Miss Torso. She is the bathroom brushing her long hair, while her thoughts s to be far away. THE CAMERA DROPS DOWN to the apartment below, occupied by the elderly lady with the hearing aid. For the first time see something of her activities inside the apartment. She wears a short smock, although her legs are still bare. Sh is hard at work on a piece of abstract sculpture. It take the form of a piece of mahogany through which a simple ho has been carved. THE CAMERA MOVES ON much farther to the left, and eventua comes to rest on the newly-weds' apartment with the shade still drawn. It MOVES ON and at last passes though Jeff's window, and  comes to rest on the two bid heads of Jeff and Lisa. Her lips are brushing lightly against his cheek as she sp
How far does a girl have to go --  before you notice her?
Jeff moves his eyes slightly to something outside the win
If she's pretty enough, she doesn't  have to go anywhere. She just has to  "be".
The salesman's apartment, just as we saw it a moment ago. The shades drawn and lights out in the bedroom, the shade and lights on in the living room and kitchen. Still no on in sight.
Well, "ain't I?" -- Pay attention to  me.
We are now able to see that Jeff's apartment is in darkne only faintly lit from the distant light of the neighbors' window. By her position, Lisa is seated on Jeff's sound k her arms around his neck.
I'm not exactly on the other side of  the room.
Your mind is. And when I want a man,  I want all of him.
She starts kissing him.
Don't you ever have any problems?
(Murmurs, kissing him) I have one now.
So do I.
(Kissing) Tell me about it.
(Slight pause) Why would a man leave his apartment  three times, on a rainy night, with  a suitcase? And come back three times?
He likes the way his wife welcomes  him home.
Not that salesman's wife. And why  didn't he go to work today?
Homework. It's more interesting.
What's interesting about a butcher's  knife and a small saw wrapped up in  a newspaper?
Nothing, thank heaven.
(Looking again) Why hasn't he gone into his wife's  bedroom all day?
I wouldn't dare answer that.
(After pause) Lisa -- there's something terribly  wrong.
She gives up trying to interest him in romance, and moves back from the embrace. THE CAMERA PULL BACK.
And I'm afraid it's with me.
Lisa stands, straightens out her dress, stretches a littl then she turns to the divan, apparently not too intereste in his observation about the salesman's life.
(Looks at Lisa) What do you think?
(Without returning  his look) Something too frightful to utter.
Jeff is thoughtful for a moment, then he relaxes and smil a little. He turns to the window to look out again. Lisa  exits the picture.
Lisa stretches herself out on the divan. Her head rest on the cushion at the far end, and she instinctively falls i an attractive pose. However, her expression is disturbed she watches Jeff.
He stares intently out the window.
He went out a few minutes ago -- in  his undershirt -- and he hasn't come  back yet.
Lisa weighs this information, trying to make some sense o of it.
Jeff turns his eyes from the salesman's apartment, and lo down reflectively. He looks up again, and then his eyes  catches sight of something. He leans forward slightly.

Miss Torso is lying, face down, on her divan bed. The onl light in the apartment is from a reading lamp. She is rea a book held in one hand, while eating a sandwich in anoth Her back is bare, and all she wears is a pair of brief da blue shorts. At one point, she lifts her torso up slightl to brush crumbs out from beneath her.
He looks away from Miss Torso, thoughtfully.
You know -- that would be terrible  job to tackle.
Lisa leans forward and looks out the window to see what J is referring to. She turns back to him with a blank stare
Jeff turns and looks at her, quite unaware of her surpris at his comment.
How would you begin to cut up a human  body?

Lisa sits bolt upright on the divan. She reaches back qui and pulls on the overhead light. At that moment the songw returns to his composing. We can see him over Lisa's shou He is beginning his song again, and it has taken on new  fullness and melody. Although it is not complete, it is farther along then bef and he plays his theme a number of different ways, trying move it note by note to its completion. Lisa just stares at Jeff for a moment.
Jeff -- I'll be honest with you --  you're beginning to scare me a little.
Jeff is staring out of the window again. Over this we hea Lisa's voice:
(Quietly insistent) Jeff -- did you hear what I said?  You're beginning to --
Jeff puts out a restraining hand.
(Interrupting) Be quiet! Shhh! (Pause) He's coming back!

At last the salesman is seen coming along the corridor. He does not wear shirt, but only an undershirt. Slung ove one shoulder, with his arm through is, is a large coil of sturdy rope. He goes through the living room into the bed He does not put on the bedroom lights.
Jeff reaches quickly for his binoculars, and trains them the salesman's apartment.

As seen though the binoculars, the salesman comes out of bedroom, to the kitchen, where he gets a carving knife. H turns around and goes back to the bedroom. The lights go on behind the draw shades, after a short mo The dim shadow of the salesman is seen moving around the  room.

Lisa, still stretched out on the divan looking at Jeff,  suddenly sits upright and then getting up from the divan, mover over to Jeff, THE CAMERA GOING WITH her. In a sudden surprise move, she swings his chair completel around so that his back is to the window. He drops the  binoculars into his lap in surprise. THE CAMERA MOVES IN Lisa leans over Jeff, gripping both sides of his chair
(sharply) Jeff -- if you could only see  yourself.
Now, Lisa --

(Abruptly) Sitting around, looking out a window  to kill time, is one thing -- but  doing it the way you are --  (She gestures) -- with, with binoculars, and with  wild opinions about every little  movement you see -- is, is diseased!
Do you think I consider this  recreation?
I don't know what you consider it --  but if you don't stop it, I'm getting  out of here.
You'd better before you catch the  disease!
(Insistent) What is it you're looking for?
I want to find out what's wrong with  the salesman's wife. Does that make  me sound like a madman?
What makes you think something's  wrong with her?
A lot of things. She's an invalid  who needs constant care -- and yet  the husband nor anyone else has been  in there all day.
Maybe she died.
Where's the doctor -- the undertakers?
She could be under sedatives,  sleeping. (Looks up) He's in the room now.
Jeff tries to turn around, but she won't let the chair mo
Lisa, please!
There's nothing to see.

There is -- I've seen things through  that window! Bickering, family fights,  mysterious trips at night, knives,  saws, rope -- and since last evening,  not a sight or sound of his wife!  Now you tell me where she is and  what she's doing!

Maybe he's leaving his wife. I don't  know, and I don't care. Lots of people  have saws, knives and ropes around  their houses. Lots of men don't speak  to their wives all day. Lots of wives  nag, and men hate them, and trouble  starts -- but very, very, very few  of them end up in murder -- if that's  what you're thinking.
It's pretty hard to stay away from  that word isn't is?
You could see all the things he did,  couldn't you?
What are you getting at?
You could see that he did because he  had the shades in his apartment up,  and walked along the corridor, and  the streets and the backyard?
Yeah.
Jeff, do you think a murderer would  let you see all that? That he  shouldn't keep his shades down and  hide behind them?
That's where he's being clever. Acting  nonchalant.
And that's where you're not being  clever. He wouldn't parade his crime  in front of the open shades.
She turns the wheelchair slightly to her left so that he see the newlyweds' apartment.
(Pointing) For all you know -- there's something  a lot more sinister going on behind  those shades.
The drawn shades of the newlyweds' apartment. A dim light burning behind them.
Jeff looks, turns back to her, trying to suppress a chuck
No comment.
Don't you see how silly you're being?
Okay, Lisa -- probably you're right.  He's probably in the bedroom now,  entertaining his wife with the indian  rope trick. I'll admit to criminal  insanity. Now when do I start the  cure?

Lisa half looks up and out the window. She opens her mout to answer, but a new look overtakes her face. It is conce surprise, and a little shock. Jeff sees the change, is  sobered, and quickly turns the chair around. He looks out the window, using his binoculars.

The shades in the bedroom are now up. Both beds are empty and stripped of their linen, the mattresses thrown up ove the end of the beds. The salesman, sweating heavily, stan over a large, square trunk in the center of the room. It stoutly bound by the heavy rope we previously saw him bri into the apartment. He wipes one forearm across his brow, and then heads for the kitchen. In the kitchen, he produc a bottle, pours himself two or three straight drinks, the leans with a display of exhaustion against the kitchen si
Jeff lowers the glasses. His look is sober. Lisa stands b him, one hand on the back of the wheelchair. She, too, is serious. THE CAMERA MOVES IN until Lisa's head fills the  screen. She says, slowly:
Let's start from the beginning again,  Jeff. Tell me everything you saw --  and what you think it means.
She is still staring out the window, as the scene
Jeff is seated in the dark, his face lit by the faint glo from the distant street. He is looking out of the window  tensely, as THE CAMERA MOVES IN, until he is in big profi

From Jeff's viewpoint, all the windows are dark. The coup are sleeping on the fire escape. The salesman's apartment dark as well. Suddenly a match flares, and we see the sal light a cigar. The flame of the match illuminates his fac for a moment. When is dies out, we see just the glow of t cigar burning.

The CAMERA is now facing Jeff. We see that his left hand  rests on the telephone receiver which is close to him. Th phone starts to RING, but makes only the slightest sound, he instantly picks it up. As he talks, in a low voice, he keeps his eyes on the salesman's apartment.
Yeah?
We get an impression of Sixth Avenue behind Lisa at the p Lisa also talks in a low, quiet voice.
The name on the second floor rear  mailbox reads Mr. And Mrs. Lars,  that's L-A-R-S, Lars Thorwald.
(Filter) What's the apartment house number?
125 West Ninth Street.
Jeff, still looks toward the salesman's apartment.
Thanks, Lisa.
Lisa smilingly says:
Okay, chief. What's my next  assignment.
To get on home.
All right -- but what's he doing  now?
Jeff is still looking toward the salesman's apartment.
Just sitting in the living room. In  the dark. And he hasn't gone near  the bedroom. Now get some sleep.  Goodnight.
He puts the receiver down, and resumes his vigil.
All we can see is the glow of the salesman's cigar.
Jeff is seated by the window in his wheelchair. He is tal on the telephone while his eyes are still on the neighbor There is a touch of urgency in his voice.
Look, Doyle -- it's just one of those  things I can't tell you on the phone.  You have to be here, and see the  whole set-up.
The CAMERA PULLS BACK slightly as Stella emerges from the kitchen. She is carrying a tray with breakfast on it. Egg bacon, toast and coffee.
It's probably nothing important --  just a little neighborhood murder,  that's all. As a matter of fact, I  did say "murder".

Stella squeezes past the right side of Jeff, and places t food tray on a windowseat in front of him. She peers out  cautiously toward Thorwald's apartment for a moment. Then she squeezes back, moving to the sideboard against which  leans a small table on an adjustable stand.
My only thought was to throw a little  business your way. A good detective,  I reasoned, would jump at the chance  to detect.

Stella returns with the table, and sets it up so that it across Jeff's lap. She gets the tray of food pausing to l toward Thorwald's apartment. Then she places the breakfas on the tray table in front of Jeff. He has moved back a l to avoid getting the phone cable tangled in the food and  dishes.
Well, I usually took my best pictures  on my day off. (nods) Okay, Doyle -- soon as you can.
He hangs up. Stella takes the phone and puts it down for  him. He looks at the breakfast, reaches for a knife and f
Stella, I -- I can't tell you what a  welcome sight this is. No wonder  your husband's still in love with  you.
Police?
(Pauses in cutting  food) Huh?
You called the police?
Oh. Well, yes and no. It wasn't an  official call. He's just a friend. (Almost to himself) An old, ornery friend.
He begins eating, appreciatively. She moves behind his ch pausing to look toward Thorwald's apartment again. Jeff i just lifting a piece of bacon to his lips when Stella spe
(Half to herself) Now just where do you suppose he cut  her up?
The hand carrying the bacon to Jeff's mouth hesitates for moment.
(Answering herself) Oh -- of course! In the bathtub.  That's the only place he could wash  away the blood.
The hand holding the bacon moves back to the plate. Jeff just stares ahead. Stella turns and walks into the  kitchen. Jeff pushes the food away, and picks up the coff cup instead.
Jeff's eyes, over the coffee cup, are staring intently at the backyard.
Thorwald's apartment. The shades up. No one moving. The rope-tied trunk still sits in the bedroom. To the left we see the basket lowering with the dog in it We HEAR the woman WHISTLING an aria.
His eyes stray in an upward direction as he puts down the coffee cup.
The CAMERA PANS UP past the woman lowering the dog, up to the roof where one of the sunbathers can be seen sitting rubbing her body with sun tan oil.
Jeff's eyes moves down again. Abstractedly his hand stray toward the piece of bacon. He picks it up.

Thorwald's apartment. We are now aware that the salesman now in his living room, lying out of sight on the sofa,  because the smoke from a newly lighted cigar is starting ascend toward the ceiling of his room. Stella's voice is heard calling out from the kitchen:
He'd better get that trunk out of  there before is starts to leak.
Again the bacon stops before is reaches Jeff's mouth. He puts it down on the plate again, as his eyes move slig toward the left.

Miss Torso, in ballet outfit, is hanging up a small wash a clothes line. It consists mostly of lingerie. She is do her inevitable leg practice at the same time. THE CAMERA PANS OVER SUDDENLY TO Thorwald's apartment, an except for the smoke rising from the unseen sofa, there i no activity.
Jeff seems to be getting a bit listless, or bored, by  constantly watching Thorwald's apartment. His eyes sort o stray around the neighborhood, and end up looking toward:
The newlywed's apartment. Shade down, business as usual.
Jeff smiles affectionately, and starts to turn his eyes a but something startles him, and he looks quickly back.

The shade suddenly going up in the newlywed's apartment. The young husband leans his hands on the windowsill, and  looks out. He is wearing only his pajama bottoms, because the heat, and we see that he is a well-muscled, attractiv young man. He looks around with some satisfaction. He tur at the sound of a woman's voice behind him.
H-a-a-r-r-e-e...
He turns his head, is thoughtful for a brief moment, then pulls down the shade.
His smile almost becomes a private chuckle. Stella's abru voice breaks in urgently:
Look! Look -- Mr. Jefferies!
Jeff's head snaps toward the center of his window. Stella has appeared behind his wheelchair.

Two men wearing tan coveralls are standing outside Thorwa door. One of them carries a clipboard. Suddenly Thorwald is seen sitting up on the living room s His hair is disheveled and he is unshaved. He stands up, moves toward the door. He opens it, and after a short exchange of dialogue, he a the two men, leaving the door open behind them. He leads the two man across the living room to the bedroo
Stella and Jeff watching intently. He is feeling down  alongside his wheelchair for his binoculars.
A close view shows the two man carrying the trunk across living room toward the corridor.
Jeff lowers the binoculars quickly.
(Agitated) I thought Doyle would get here before  the trunk went -- or I'd have called  the police. (To Stella) Now we're going to lose it.
Stella moves toward the door quickly. Jeff turns quickly  over his shoulder to watch her. She is already going up t steps.
Stella, don't do anything reckless!
As Stella goes out the door, she calls back:
I'm just going to get the name of  their truck!
(Up) I'll watch the alleyway -- in case  it goes that way.
We hear nothing from Stella, but the sound of her heavy t down the hallway stairs. Jeff returns to Thorwald. He eas himself back into the shadows a bit and then raises his  binoculars.

Jeff concentrates his attention on the alley-way that lea to the street. Just normal traffic. The binoculars swing Thorwald apartment. The salesman is now at the telephone. has picked up the receiver, and proceeds to dial 221.
The binoculars still up to Jeff's face. Under them his mo moves, as if he's talking to himself.
Long Distance.

The salesman speaks some words to the operator. Placing t call. As he does this, he reaches with his other hand for nearly bottle, and working the cork out with one hand, he pours a stiff drink into a tumbler. He drinks it as soon he finishes talking with the operator.
Jeff lowers the binoculars a little, and takes a normal e sight on the alleyway.
Pulling across to the far side of the street we see the h and cab of a freight truck.
Jeff quickly puts the glasses up.

By the time the binoculars are up, another truck has cros from the left. In momentarily blocks out the side of our  freight truck. By the time the two trucks part, we can on see the back half of the freight truck before it pulls ou of sight. Jeff is only able to read the words "FREIGHT LI The binoculars are held for a moment until we see a puffi and blowing Stella arrive at the opening of the alleyway. She looks toward the front of Thorwald's apartment house. And by her attitude we can see that there is no truck out She looks about her for a moment.
Jeff lowers the binoculars, discouraged.
The figure of Stella is seen, looking up toward Jeff's  apartment, and arms outspread in a helpless gesture.

SHOOTING TOWARDS the big window, with the neighborhood be Jeff is as usual seated in his wheelchair on the left of window, but now turned toward a newcomer. The second man is standing near the divan looking out the window with the binoculars. This newcomer is POLICE DETEC LIEUTENANT THOMAS J. DOYLE, the man Jeff phoned earlier i the day. He is an intelligent-appearing, well-dressed mod detective. He has a sense of humor. He lowers the glasses and turns to Jeff.
You didn't see the killing, or the  body? How do you know there was a  murder?
Because everything that man's done  has been suspicious. Trips at night  in the rain, saws, knives, trunks  with rope, and a wife that isn't  there any more.
I'll admit it all has a mysterious  sound -- but is could mean a number  of different things. Murder is the  least likely.
Go ahead, Doyle -- tell me he's an  unemployed magician -- amusing the  neighborhood with sleight-of-hand.
Doyle paces a little.
It's too stupid and obvious a way to  murder -- in full view of fifty  windows -- and then sit over there -- (He points) -- smoking a cigar -- waiting for  the police to pick him up.
Well, officer -- do your duty.

You've got a lot to lean about  homicide, Jeff. Morons have committed  murder so shrewdly that it took a  hundred trained police minds to catch  them. That salesman wouldn't just  knock off his wife after dinner,  toss her in a trunk and put her in  storage.
I'll bet it's been done.
Almost everything's been done --  under panic. But this is a thousand  to one shot. That man's still sitting  around his apartment; he isn't  panicked.
(A pause) You think I made all this up?
I think you saw something -- that  probably has a very simple  explanation.
For instance?
(Shrugs) His wife took a trip.
She -- was -- an -- invalid!
You told me. (Looks at watch) I've got to run, Jeff.
All right -- you don't believe me.
Doyle saunters toward steps, picking up his hat on the wa Stops.
I -- uh -- won't report it to the  Department. Let me poke into a little  on my own. No point in you getting  any ridiculous publicity.
(Coldly) Thanks.
We know the wife is gone. I'll see  if I can find out where.
Do that.
He goes up the steps to the door, putting on his hat. He pauses his hand on the door knob.
You have any headaches lately?
Jeff answers, showing only the slightest irritation.
Not 'til you showed up.
Doyle, still at the door:
Uh-huh. Well, it'll wear off in time --  along with the hallucinations. See  you around.
He starts to go out the door, and closes it behind him.
From Doyle's viewpoint. Jeff lifts his hand in a feeble  parting gesture.
Before the door has completely closed, Doyle opens it aga and looks in.
By the way  what happened to your  leg?
I was jaywalking.
Where?
(With nonchalance) The Indianapolis Speedway.
The door starts to close again, as if Doyle considered Je answer quite reasonable. Then the door pops open and Doyl head comes in, a surprised expression across his face.
During the race?
Jeff answers with a straight face.
Yup. It sure stopped traffic.
We don't see Doyle again, but only HEAR the sharp slam of the DOOR off. Jeff chuckles. Then he turns back to the wi
Jeff's attention is drawn to something in the yard below.
The little dog is busily scratching away at Thorwald's pe flower bed.
Jeff smiles mischievously. Suddenly his face changes as h sees:

Thorwald coming out of his basement door, carrying a wate can. He fills it from a nearby faucet. He does not notice the little dog's destructive activities. When the watering can is filled, he straightens up, turns toward the flower bed. He stops for the briefest moment,  when he sees the dog. He walks to the dog, gently lifts h out of the garden, and giving him a friendly little pat,  sends him off. He proceeds to patiently brush back the  disturbed earth, and then begins his watering.
Jeff is frankly puzzled by the salesman's friendly attitu toward the dog. He looks off in another direction, as he  catches of:

Doyle, who has appeared, at the street opening. The detec is surveying the front of the apartment building where  Thorwald lives. A paper seller behind him offers to sell a paper. Doyle isn't interested. As Doyle saunters forward toward the salesman house, the  scene:
Doyle is nonchalantly leaning up against the side board,  with a highball in one hand. Jeff has turned his chair ar from the window to face him.

He has a six months lease, and has  used up a little over five and a  half months of it. (Takes a sip of drink) Quiet. Drinks, but not to drunkenness.  Pays his bill promptly, with money  earned as a consume jewelry salesman --  wholesale. Keeps to himself, and  none of the neighbors got close to  him, or his wife.
I think they missed their chance  with her.
(Studies drink) She never left the apartment --
(Interrupting) Then where is she -- in the ice box?
(Continues) -- until yesterday morning.
(Alert) What time?
Six ayem.
Jeff looks thoughtful a moment, and then says, with a tou of discouragement:
I think that's about the time I fell  asleep.
Too bad. The Thorwalds were just  leaving the apartment house at that  time.
He puts down his drink, and strolls toward the window, lo out. THE CAMERA MOVES IN slightly to tighten the shot.
Feel a little foolish?
Not yet.
Doyle becomes interested in watching something out the wi Unconsciously he smooths out his coat and tie. He even smiles somewhat secretly to himself at what he se
Miss Torso, in ballet costume, practicing her dance on th outside balcony. She is exciting and desirable.
Jeff notices Doyle's interest.
How's your wife?
Startled at being observed, Doyle moves quickly away from the window, affecting nonchalance. THE CAMERA MOVES BACK Doyle returns to his drink. Jeff smiles at catching Doyle enjoying Miss Torso.
Oh -- oh, she's fine. (Not too convincing) Just fine.
He tosses off the rest of the drink, and his movement is  almost a comment. Jeff's face grows serious.
Who said they left then?
Who left -- where?
The Thorwalds -- at six in the  morning?
Doyle quickly collects his thoughts, and gets back to the case at hand.
The building superintendent, and two  tenants. Flat statements -- no  hesitation. And they all jibed to  the letter. The Thorwalds were leaving  for the railroad station.
Now how could anybody guess that?  They had, perhaps, signs on their  luggage, "Grand Central Or Bust!"?
(Sighs) The superintendent met Thorwald coming  back. He said Thorwald told him he  had just put his wife on the train  for the country.
A very convenient guy -- this  superintendent. Have you checked his  bank deposits lately?
Jeff -- huh?
(Sharply) Well -- what good is his  information?!! It's a second-hand  version of an unsupported statement  by the murderer himself -- Thorwald!  Anybody actually see the wife get on  the train?
I hate to remind you -- but this all  started because you said she was  murdered. Now did anyone, including  you, actually see her murdered?
Doyle -- are you interested in solving  a case, or making me look foolish?
If possible -- both.
Well then do a good job of it! Get  over there, and search Thorwald's  apartment! It must be knee-deep in  evidence.
I can't do that.
I mean when he goes out for a paper,  or a drink, or something. What he  doesn't know won't hurt him.
I can't do it even if he's gone.
(With sarcasm) What's the matter? Does he have a  courtesy card from the police  department?
Now don't get me mad! Even a detective  can't walk in anybody's apartment  and search it. If I were ever caught  in there, I'd lose my badge inside  of ten minutes!
Just make sure you're not caught. If  you find something, you've got a  murderer and nobody will care about  a couple of house rules. If you find  nothing -- he's clear.
At the risk of sounding stuffy, Jeff --  I'll remind you of the Constitution,  and the phrase "search warrant" issued  by a judge who knows the Bill of  Rights verbatim. He must ask for  evidence.
Give him evidence.

I can hear myself starting out. "Your  Honor -- I have a friend who's an  amateur sleuth, an one night, after  a heavy supper --" (He shakes his head  "no") He'd throw the New York State Penal  Code right in my face. -- And it's  six volumes.
By morning there might not be anything  left to find in his apartment.
(Looking out window) A detective's nightmare.
What do you need before you can search --  bloody footsteps leading up to the  door?
(Looking out window) One thing I don't need is heckling!  You called and asked me for help --  and now you're acting like a taxpayer!
(Turns and look at  Jeff) How did we ever stand each other in  that same plane for three years?
You know, every day for three years  I asked myself that same question?
Ever get an answer?
Yeah -- frequently -- it ran something  like this: "Your request for transfer  turned down --"
He can't help smiling, and neither can Doyle.
Sorry I had to turn it down. (He checks his watch) I'm going over to the railroad station  and check Thorwald's story.
He moves to the sideboard, picks up a felt hat.
Forget the story -- find the trunk.  Mrs. Thorwald's in it!
Oh -- I almost forgot!
He pulls a slip of paper out of his pocket. Jeff watches intently.

(Looking at Jeff) There was a postcard in Thorwald's  mailbox. (Refers to paper) Mailed yesterday afternoon, three-  thirty P.M. from Merritsville -- (Looks up, speaks  pleasantly) -- That's eighty miles north of here. (Back to paper) The message read "Arrived O.K. Already  feeling better. Love, Anna."
He looks at Jeff with some smugness.
(Slowly) Is -- is Anna -- who I think it is?
(Nods "yes") Mrs. Thorwald.
He puts on his hat, and goes toward the door.
(Maliciously) Anything you need?
Jeff is sober.
Yeah. A good detective.

The sun has just set. THE CAMERA is concentrating on the  long-focus lens camera which fills the screen. Just beyon there is a plate on which a solitary sandwich. Jeff's hand comes in, picks it up. We PAN US with the san until Jeff's head fills the screen. (Except for a small l in the kitchen, Jeff's apartment is in darkness.) As he  munches, he keeps his attention on the neighborhood.

Thorwald's apartment is darkness. THE CAMERA PANS slightl to the left, as we see the dog being lowered in its baske We follow the basket down to the yard which brings Miss L Heart's apartment into view. She is wearing a Kelly Green suit, and is seated at her dressing table. She seems to b putting on the final touches of her make-up, prior to goi out.
Jeff looks down, he smiles to himself. He turns, and we s him raise the long-focus camera to his eye.

The long-focus lens brings Miss Lonely Hearts into an enl picture which reveals details we have not previously noti A pair of ill-fitting, horn-rimmed reading glasses rest h way down her nose, and she has to tilt her head back slig as she applies lip-stick, with their aid. Satisfied, she takes off the glasses, and examines her fa as a whole, through squinting eyes. She has faded good lo has fairly nice clothes, but is badly in need of advice o hair dressing. Her hair-do makes her seem middle-aged. Sh reaches for a tall glass of liquor next to her, and takes long drink. Putting the glass down, she squints to see if she has disturbed the lipstick. Unable to see clearly, sh puts on the glasses again, looks, and touches up her lips slightly. She puts her glasses in a handbag, then stands to put out the lights. She walks into the living room, finishing the drink. The long-focus lens moves with her. She goes strai for a bottle of liquor, and pours out a final neat slug, tosses it off. Then she leaves the apartment, with a show determination. She turns out the lights behind her.
Jeff lowers the long-focus lens, and turns his head to th right as he hears the first notes of the songwriter's mel which we have heard him trying to complete.

The songwriter is at the piano, poking out his melody, sl note by note. He is in black tie, and from the looks of t apartment he is preparing for guests. An attractive girl setting out trays of canapes, glasses, ice and liquor. Sh pauses as she crosses the room carrying a tray of food. S listens a moment to the songwriter's melody. Her expressi shows that it pleases her, and moves her romantically. Sh comments on it to the songwriter, who starts from the  beginning again, playing it more fully.
A new source of music comes in to interfere with the pian playing. It is orchestral ballet music, in a modern style Jeff's head turns in this new direction.

Miss Torso, and a male partner whom we have not seen befo are practicing a pas a deux. He is a tall flowing-haired  young man, lithe and graceful beyond normal masculine  capacity. They stop, at one point, to listen to a word of comment f a woman who is watching. By her gestures, she is obviousl professional choreographer. THE CAMERA PANS from this to the street beyond. Standing there, on the sidewalk, looking up and down the  street is a Kelly Green clad figure.
He quickly raises his long-focus camera to his eye.

We are now given a waist-high shot as the focus is adjust by Jeff. The figure is that of Miss Lonely Hearts. She se to be trying to figure out what to do, or where to go. Sh nervously looks at a couple of men passers by. Getting no reaction, she crosses the street, and seats herself at an empty table in front of the cafe. She orders a drink. She is suddenly blotted out by a figure of a man who ente the picture from the left side. He is much nearer the len because he is on this side of the street. He is, therefor slightly out of focus. The lens suddenly sharpens. It is  Thorwald, carrying a light-weight cardboard box under his arm. THE CAMERA PANS him over to the right until he is lo behind the building.

He lowers the lens, and we see Jeff's eyes travel across screen, as he imagines Thorwald's progression. Then sharp his look, he picks up the long-focus lens, and easing him back cautiously, begins watching Thorwald.

Thorwald comes up the corridor, and stands unlocking his  door. As he hesitates, we are able to see the cardboard b he is carrying has the name of a laundry on it. He enters the apartment turns on the living room lights. He proceeds to the bedroom, and the lights go on there. A number of suits and top coats are lying on an orderly p on the bed. He takes the laundry out of the box and puts on the bed next to the suits. Then he goes to the dresser and instead of putting the laundry away, he proceeds to take out the contents of the drawers --  pajamas, shirts, sox, etc. He piles these on the beds.
Jeff lowers the camera quickly. He picks up the phone and dials a number, still keeping his eyes on Thorwald. The phone buzzes on filter, then is picked up and answere by a woman:
(Filter) Hello.
Mrs. Doyle?
Yes.
Jeff again. (A note of urgency) Has Tom come in yet?
Not yet, Jeff.
You haven't even heard from him?
Not a word.
For a moment, Jeff looks desperate. He doesn't know what say.
It is something really important,  Jeff?
I'm afraid it is, Tess.
I'll have him call the moment I hear  from him.
Tell him not to waste time calling.  To get over here soon as he can. I  think Thorwald's pulling out tonight.
Who's Thorwald?
He knows. (As an after-thought) Don't worry, Tess. It's a man.
(She laughs) Goodnight, you idiot.
(A slight smile) Goodnight, Mrs Doyle.
He hangs up. Then, his brows knit a little, as if he's pu about something he sees across the neighborhood. He lifts up the long-focus lens.

Early night. In the dresser Thorwald finds an alligator  handbag. He holds it up thoughtfully. We have previously  seen this handbag hanging from the bedpost when Mrs. Thor was in bed. Thorwald takes the bag into the living room,  where he picks up the phone and dials.
Long distance again.

Thorwald reaches his party. As he talks, thoughtfully, he takes some jewelry from the handbag -- a couple of rings, diamond wristwatch, brooch, pearls, etc. He discusses eac piece, apparently trying to make some decision. Then,  seemingly satisfied, he replaces them in the bag and hang up.

Jeff lowers his camera lens and edges his chair forward i an effort to hear what Thorwald is saying. But a sudden r in the SOUND coming from the song-writer's apartment, cau him to turn his head toward the studio with exasperation.

The first four of the song-writer's guests come through t door, admitted by the song-writer's girl friend. There is a squeal from the woman who great each other, an hearty "helloes" from the men. The song-writer dashes off LOUD VAMP of greeting on the piano, then gets up to offer drinks.
Jeff turns his attention back to Thorwald, but gives up a attempt at listening. He lift the long-focus lens up to h eyes again.

Having completed his call, Thorwald returns to the bedroo carrying the handbag. He goes to a pile of coats lying on the bed. He lifts the top two coats slightly, and slides handbag under them and out of sight.
There is the SOUND of footsteps coming down the corridor Jeff's apartment. He lowers the camera lens, and turns hi attention to his door.
The door opens, and Lisa stands silhouetted in the entran black-lighted by the corridor lights. It's an attractive  picture.
Jeff's head is turned toward her, his back more toward th neighborhood.
Quick. Take a look. Thorwald's getting  ready to pull out for good!
Jeff abruptly turns back to the window, as Lisa dashes in the picture behind him, and looks out. Jeff's expression  changes a little, as they see:

The lights are out in Thorwald's bedroom, and Thorwald is the act of pouring himself out a drink in the living room He comes to the window, glass in hand, and looks down int the garden, nonchalantly. Over this, we HEAR Lisa's voice questioningly:
It doesn't seem to be in any hurry.
(Stares out the window,  exasperated) He was just laying all his things  out on one of the beds! Coats, suits,  shirts, sox, even his wife's --
He stops, turns to her quickly.
That alligator bag his wife had on  the bedpost --
What about it?

He had it hidden in the dresser!  Well, at least it was in there. He  took it out, went to the phone and  called somebody long distance. --  His wife's jewelry was in the handbag.  And something about it worried him.  He was asking somebody advice over  the phone.
Someone not his wife?
I never saw him ask her for advise  before. (Smiles) But she volunteered plenty.
Jeff turns back to the window.

Thorwald is standing at the window with his drink in his  hand. Then he turns, puts his unfinished drink down on a  table, and goes to the door. He puts the light out in the living room and goes out the door. He walks briskly down corridor.
I wonder where he's going now?
I don't know.
Suppose he doesn't come back again?
He will. All his things are still  piled on the bed.
Lisa moves toward a nearby lamp.
Well, I guess it's safe to put on  some lights now.
(Looking to left) Not yet!
He picks up the long-focus lens and trains it on the stre intersection, as Lisa moves back to him.
The street intersection. Some traffic, mostly pedestrian. Miss Lonely Hearts still sitting at the cafe table, alone Drinking. There is no sign of Thorwald.
He lowers the lens.
He must have gone somewhere to the  right.

The CAMERA PULLS BACK as Lisa starts around the apartment turning on the lights. As she light increases, we see tha she is wearing another extravagantly beautiful dress. She seems quite animated, moving gracefully, her skirt and ha swinging with her movement. Jeff turns around to face the room.
All day long I've tried to keep my  mind on work.
Thinking about Thorwald?
(Nods yes) And you, and you friend Doyle -- (Stops, to Jeff) Did you hear from him again -- since  he left?
Not a word. He was going to check on  the railroad station, and the trunk.  He must be still on it.

As he talks, she seems to be thinking something over to  herself. He starts pacing, trying to distill her thoughts We see that she has brought an oversized handbag with her which lies prominently on the table. Jeff watches her.
Something on your mind, Lisa?
It doesn't make sense to me.
What doesn't?
Women aren't that unpredictable.
(Losing a little  patience) Lisa -- I can't guess what you're  thinking.
THE CAMERA CLOSES IN, Lisa stops, faces him. Her eyes spa and her body is tense with concentration.
A woman has a favorite handbag -- it  always hangs on her bedpost where  she can get at it. Then she takes a  trip and leaves it behind. Why?
Because she didn't know she was going  on a trip -- and where she was going  she wouldn't need a handbag.
THE CAMERA eases back.
But only her husband would know that. (Starts to pace again) And the jewelry! Women don't keep  all their jewelry in a purse, all  tangled, getting scratched and twisted  up.
Do they hide it in their husband's  clothes?
They do not! And they don't leave it  behind them. A woman going anywhere  but the hospital would always take  makeup, perfume and jewelry.
Inside stuff?
Basic equipment. You don't leave it  behind in your husband's drawer in  your favorite handbag.
I'm with you, sweetie, but Detective  Thomas J. Doyle has a pat answer for  that.
That Mrs. Thorwald left at six ayem  yesterday with her husband?
That's what the witnesses told him.
Well, I have a pat rebuttal for Mr.  Doyle -- that couldn't be Mrs.  Thorwald -- or I don't know women.
Still -- those witnesses.
We'll agree they saw a woman -- but  she wasn't Mrs. Thorwald. -- That  is, yet.
She comes over to Jeff. He reaches up, takes her hand.
Come here.
He pulls her into his lap. She puts her arms around him. is very happy, and kisses Jeff's cheek.
I'd like to see your friend's face  when we tell him. He doesn't sound  like much of a detective.
Don't be too hard on him. He's a  steady worker. I wish he'd get there,  though.
(Nuzzling Jeff) Don't rush me. We have all night.
There's a pause. Then Jeff moves back a little to look he straight in the eye.
We have all -- what?
Night. I'm going to stay with you.
You'll have to clear that through my  landlord --
She cuts him off with a kiss. When she pulls back
I have the whole weekend off.
Well that's fine, but I only have  one bed, and --
Lisa smothers him with another kiss. She lets up.
Say anything else, and I'll stay  tomorrow night too.
Lisa, I won't be able to give you  any --
She smothers him with still another kiss. Then moves back
-- pajamas.
She laughs, gets up. Goes to the large handbag on the tab Is is a Mark Cross ladies 'attache' case.
You said I'd have to live out of one  suitcase (Picks up case) I'll bet yours isn't this small?
That's a suitcase?
(Starting to open it) A Mark Cross overnight case, anyway.  Compact, but ample enough.

She has opened it, and surprisingly enough, it is a compa outfit of pajamas, slippers, toothbrush, toothpaste, and the general necessities for a comfortable overnight stay. She comes to Jeff, sits in his lap again, displaying the  inside of the case
I'll trade you -- my feminine  intuition for a bed for the night.
(Gives in smiling) I'd be no better than Thorwald, to  refuse.
The SOUND from the party in the song-writer's apartment  becomes more noticeable as his party grows. And at this p he begins playing the song he has been composing for the  past few days.
There's that song again.
She gets up from Jeff's lap, and puts the overnight case the table. Open. She goes to the window, and looks toward the song-writers' apartment. Jeff turns with her.

The party at the song-writer's has grow considerably larg An assortment of well-dressed people have now crowded int the studio. They are drinking, eating, etc. At the moment number of them are crowded around the piano, listening to the composer's newest song -- which isn't quite completed However, the melody has become more beautiful than ever.  During the following scene, we HEAR the melody being play a number of different ways on the piano.
Lisa stands, listening, entranced.
Where does a man get the inspiration  for a song like that?
Jeff watches her.
From his landlord -- once a month.
It's utterly beautiful. (Turns to Jeff) I wish I could be creative.
You are. You have a talent for  creating difficult situations.
(Happily) I do?
Staying the night here, uninvited.
She sits down on the edge of the divan near Jeff. She lea toward him.

Surprise -- is the most important  element of attack. (She smiles) And beside, you're not up on your  private eye literature. When they're  in trouble, it's always their Girl  Friday who gets them out of it.
The same girl who keeps him out of  the clutches of seductive show girls,  and over-passionate daughters of the  rich.
The same.
But he never ends up marrying her.  Strange.
(Stands up; deadpan) Weird. (She does a complete  spin, then,  ingenuously) Why don't I slip into something  comfortable?
You mean -- like the kitchen? And  make us some coffee?
Exactly what I had in mind -- along  with some brandy.
She goes to the kitchen, humming with the song-writer's m which we can HER off. Jeff turns back to the window, look out.

The shade is going up in the newlyweds apartment. The you husband throws up the window an lights a cigarette. He ta a deep and satisfying drag on the cigarette, glancing tow the song-writer's party. Just as he starts to exhale the smoke, we HEAR his young  wife's voice off:
H-a-a-r-r-e-e-!

He chokes on the smoke, sputtering and coughing. When he  recovers, he throws the cigarette down to the back-yard w a show of irritation. Then slowly he pulls the shade down Behind us is SOUND of a door shutting
Over Jeff's shoulder we see Doyle coming down the steps  slowly, and seemingly preoccupied. Jeff swings the chair  around so that his back is to us.

Without looking at Jeff, Doyle comes into the apartment t off his hat and places it on the table. He runs a hand ov the side of his head and down the back of his neck, which seems to indicate some fatigue.
Jeff. Looking expectantly at Doyle.
Doyle reaches for a cigarette on the table, and puts it t his lips. While searching his pockets for a match, he HEA Lisa humming. His eyes turn upward.
Over the cabinet which divides the living room from the  kitchen, we can see a glimpse of Lisa's shadow on the cei
Jeff, has followed Doyle's look.
Doyle picks up cigarette lighter from table, and lights h cigarette. As he is placing the lighter back on the table he sees:
From his viewpoint, Lisa's bag containing her lingerie an overnight effects.
Jeff. His eyes turn from the lingerie up to Doyle.

Doyle's look is completely noncommittal. His eyes turn at the sound of the song-writer's party. He moves forward to get a better view, as the CAMERA RETREATS in front of him He stops to glance out of the window.

The party is now full progress. The room is overcrowded. some people are now sitting on the floor with their backs the window. Others are outside. A crowd hides the piano  player, but music can be head competing with the babble.
Doyle turns his head away, and looks straight out. His  expression hardens a little, as he sees:
The window of Thorwald's apartment, completely dark.
He also is looking toward Thorwald's apartment. He turns eyes anxiously back to Doyle. He seems to be trying to  penetrate Doyle's mind.
Doyle turns his head from the window, and looks down at J He asks, quietly:
What else do you have on this man  Thorwald?
Jeff's tension eases off a little, by he is eager to talk
Enough to scare me that you wouldn't  get here in time, and we'd lose him.
(Soberly) You think he's getting out of here?
Everything he owns is laid out on  the bedroom, ready for packing.

Doyle looks back toward Thorwald's bedroom. We see the da apartment beyond him. Doyle nods thoughtfully. He turns h head suddenly at the sound of Lisa coming out of the kitc She holds two large brandy snifters containing some brand They are cupped in her hand, the stem between her fingers She is rotating them gently toward the body to warm the  brandy. She is quite beautiful.
Doyle reacts to her appreciatively.
She continues rotating the brandy.
I'm just warming some brandy.

She comes forward hands one snifter to Jeff. She offers t second to Doyle. (NOTE: In the following set of scenes,  whenever anyone holds a brandy snifter, it is being rotat regardless of their attitudes.)
Mr. Doyle? -- I presume.
Doyle sort of smiles, and takes the snifter awkwardly.
Tom, this is Miss Lisa Fremont.
Doyle bows his head slightly, but his eyes remain on her a fixed stare.
How do you do?
Lisa smiles in return.
We think Thorwald's guilty.
She turns around, and goes right back into the kitchen.
Doyle stares after her, ignoring her remark, still not  recovered from the fist sight of her attractiveness. Then quickly, his eyes move down and to the left.
The open overnight case with its displayed lingerie.
Slowly Doyle's eyes travel back to Jeff.
Quickly guessing what's on Doyle's mind
(Cautiously) Careful, Tom.

Doyle's eyes travel past Jeff to look out the window. He still holds the brandy snifter in one hand, and a ciga in the other. Absentmindedly he still rotates the brandy. The SOUND of the phone ringing is heard.
Jeff picks up the phone.
Hallo?
He listens, and then looks up to Doyle.
Just a minute, please.
Doyle crosses and stands behind Jeff, as Jeff hands him t Phone. He juggles the cigarette, the brandy snifter and t phone all at once. This is all done deadpan.
Doyle speaking. (He listens) Uh-huh. -- Yeah. Mummmm -- Mmm. Hmm --  Okay. Thank you, and goodbye.
He hands the receiver back to Jeff, who hangs up. Lisa co back in with her own brandy snifter, rotating it.
The coffee will be ready soon. (Urgent) Jeff, aren't you going to tell him  about the jewelry?
Doyle looks suddenly interested. He asks tersely:
Jewelry?
He has his wife's jewelry hidden in  among his clothes over there.
You sure it belongs to his wife?
He turns his head to Lisa, who answers.
It was in her favorite handbag --  And, Mr. Doyle, that can lead to  only one conclusion.
Namely?
His head snaps back to Jeff, who answers:
That wasn't Mrs. Thorwald who left  with him yesterday morning?
You figured that out, huh?
His head moves back to Lisa as she answers with a touch o pride in her voice.
It's just that women don't leave  jewelry behind when they go on a  trip.
Before Doyle can comment, Jeff asks impatiently:
Come on, Tom -- you don't really  need any of this information, do  you?
Doyle smiles at Jeff, and then strolls over to the table  where he puts out his cigarette and puts down the brandy  snifter.
As a matter of fact, I don't.
Doyle goes to the window and looks out, as they watch him expectantly. He speaks without looking at them. His voice is flat and to the point.
Lars Thorwald is no more a murderer  than I am.
Jeff and Lisa stare at him in astonishment. Then Jeff  recovers, and answers with some anger:
You mean you can explain everything  that went on over there -- and is  still going on?
He spins around, and his face has lost all its friendline
No!
He starts to place the room.
And neither can you. (Points out window) That's a secret and private world  you're looking into out there. People  do a lot at things in private that  they couldn't explain in public.
Lisa and Jeff. She replies with some sarcasm.
Like disposing of their wives?
(Off) Get that idea out of your mind. It  will only lead you in the wrong  direction.
But Tom -- the saw, the knives --
Doyle breaks in, takes a step forward.
Did you ever own a saw?
(Off) Well, in the garage, back home, we --
(Interrupts) And how many people did you cut up  with the couple of with it? Or hundred  knives you've probably owned in your  lifetime?
Jeff, reasoning:
But I'm not a killer!
(Off) Your logic is backward.

Thorwald crosses the living room, and goes into the bedro Suddenly he looks onto the bed. He picks up the open alli handbag. He turns, facing the window, looking down at the bag. Lisa edging toward the door, points to it as she apparent argues with him as to the way she came in. He points to the window. Her head snaps back against head rest. With his right hand he throws the handbag acro the room in anger, and with his left open-palmed he deman something from Lisa. An angry Jeff is staring, and trying to penetrate the sem darkness of Thorwald's room. Then he bends his head forwa in despair, and after a brief moment speaks:
(With deep sincerity) Stella -- what can we do?
Stella staring out, tense, frightened. Then her expressio changes sharply as she looks slightly to the left.

Two policemen move quickly and professionally up the corr toward Thorwald's apartment. They stop at the door, liste moment, and then push the buzzer insistently. She is surprised at the interruption as Thorwald. He listens, lo back questioningly toward Lisa, then goes to the door. He passes into the kitchen.

Thorwald's head and shoulders fill the screen. For a mome Thorwald is genuinely frightened by the sight of the poli We see him listening to the policeman out of the picture. THE LENS PANS UPWARD AND ACROSS until it brings Thorwald' profile into the picture. He is looking down directly at  Lisa's hands. His head slowly turns, and he looks right u directly into the lens. Suddenly he becomes aware that Li is signaling to someone who is watching him.

When you took your first snapshot --  did you ever think it would bring  you to this?

Jeff points to a drawer in the wall cabinets.

First offense burglary -- (He shrugs) -- probably two-fifty. (Gets an idea, points) The piggy bank.

Stella goes up to the door. The phone RINGS. Jeff grabs i picks it up. Stella pauses.
(To phone) Just a minute. (To Stella) I'll tell you who it is when you get  back.
Stella goes quickly out the door. He returns to the phone call, glancing at the same time toward the courtyard.
Jefferies.
(Filter) This is Doyle, Jeff.
(Urgently) Tom, I've got something real big for  you.
(Wearily) Look Jeff, don't louse up my night  with another man killer stuffing a  grisly trunk that turns out to be --
(Interrupting harshly) Listen to me! Lisa's been arrested.
(Slightest pause) Your Lisa?
My Lisa. She went into Thorwald's  apartment, and he came back. The  only way I could get her out was to  call the police.
(Angry) I told you that --
(Interrupting) I know what you told me! She went in  to get evidence, and she came out  with it.
Like what?
Like Mrs. Thorwald's wedding ring.  If that woman were still alive, she'd  be wearing it.
(Grudgingly) A possibility.
(Talking fast) A fact! Last night he killed a dog  for pawing in his garden. Why? Because  he had something buried in there.  Something a dog could scent.
Like an old hambone?

(Fast) I don't know what pet name Thorwald  had for his wife. And that night he  went out half a dozen times with the  metal suitcase. He wasn't taking his  possessions, because they're up in  his apartment now!

In sections! And one other thing,  doubting Tom -- it just occurred to  me that all the calls Thorwald made  were long distance! If he called his  wife the day she left -- after she  arrived in Merritsville -- why did  she need to send him a postcard saying  she'd arrived?
(After pause; a  detective) Where'd they take Lisa?
Precinct Six. I sent a friend over  with bail money.

We see Thorwald leave his apartment and proceed down the  corridor.
Just don't dally. Thorwald knows  he's being watched. He won't hang  around long.
If that ring checks out, we'll give  him an escort. So long.

Thorwald's apartment. Completely dark. No movement, or gl of a cigar. The corridor outside lighted, but empty.

He moves forward a couple of steps.
(Sudden loud anger) Say something! Tell me what you want!

(Loud) Tell her to bring it back!

From a three-quarter angle toward Thorwald. Jeff lifts th flash holder to face level and closes his eyes. He explod the flash.

Jeff ejects the used bulb and quickly inserts another. He works furiously, sweating. He gets the bulb in the fla holder just in time to meet Thorwald coming at him. Jeff  closes his eyes and another bulb explodes in Thorwald's f
Thorwald's face, full screen again, as he recoils from th flash.
The apartment as seen by Thorwald again. Big, twisting ba of blinding yellow.
Thorwald stumbles back against the side table, knocking  objects off onto the floor, struggling for balance and si Jeff works rapidly to put a fresh bulb in the holder.

Thorwald regains his equilibrium and some of his sight. Orienting himself, he starts for Jeff again. This time, w the flash holder goes off, we see it from Jeff's angle.  Thorwald is lighted almost white, shockingly outlining ev detail of his face, clothes, hands. His rage and frustrat are fixed for a brief but terrifying moment. From Thorwald's apartment shooting at Jeff's window. A su bright flash is seen as the last flash bulb goes off. And lights the scene of Jeff in the wheelchair and Thorwald d through the air at him. Darkness rushes in, blacker than  before.
